urn:contentItem:60DV-CKP1-JB20-G0M5-00000-00Bill Ackman is Interviewed on the Biggest SPAC Ever, Reopening the Economy and Tesla; Self-Censoring Politics2020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTBill Ackman, Gianno Caldwell, Mark Tepper, Larry Kudlow, Jan Hakon ErichsenNEWSInternational072303cb.231Bill Ackman is Interviewed on the Biggest SPAC Ever, Reopening the Economy and Tesla; Self-Censoring PoliticsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jackie DeAngelis

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 23rd.

Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the nose on the East Coast.

Tesla's earnings in question this morning. The stock is soaring pre-market after beating expectations with earnings. However, my sources are telling me exclusively that the numbers were boosted by skipping rent payments. More on my exclusive story coming up this morning.

U.S.-China tensions are rising. The FBI says China is harboring a fugitive at its San Francisco consulate. We have the very latest on this ongoing story.

More help for Americans likely on the way. Republicans expected to announce a trillion dollar program today as the clock ticks down to end the extra unemployment benefits.

Unrest in America deepens. Portland rocked by violent protests once again overnight. President Trump is trying to bring safety and security back to America's cities, announcing a surge in federal law enforcement.

And Twitter is soaring in the pre-market. The social media giant announcing its highest ever increase in daily users, but it also reported advertising revenue declined 23 percent.

Markets are higher this morning. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading. Take a look, Dow futures right now with a gain of 83 points. The Nasdaq is up 71, and the S&P 500 up 9.25. This on top of hopes of a new stimulus plan. Optimism over a coronavirus vaccine fueled gains yesterday.

At 4:00 on Wall Street, the DowIndustrials were up 165, the Nasdaq was up 25 and the S&P was up 18 points.

Play ball. It is baseball's opening day. Games are going to be played without fans in attendance.

Plus, it is day four of our weeklong look at Instagram stars. Later this hour, an account that is blowing up online, gaining popularity with destructive art.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

Some of the top stories that we are watching this morning, a new coronavirus relief bill clears a major hurdle. Senate Republicans reportedly set to release their $1 trillion plan today after reaching a tentative agreement with the White House. The bill includes $16 billion for testing, $105 billion to help reopen schools, money for protective equipment, like masks and gowns, and another round of stimulus checks. One key sticking point among Republicans, President Trump's push for a payroll tax cut. The extra $600 in jobless benefits runs out just days from now on the 31st.

Well, the unrest in America deepens. President Trump announces his administration is sending more federal agents to several U.S. cities to stop a growing outbreak of violence. It is called Operation LeGend, named for a four-year-old boy who was shot and killed while he slept in his Kansas City, Missouri, home last month. The program now expanding to places like Chicago and Albuquerque.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The effort to shut down policing in their own communities has led to a shocking explosion of shootings, killings, murders and heinous crimes of violence. This bloodshed must end. This blood shed will end.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Portland has filed a temporary restraining order against federal agents already in the city. It's accusing them of detaining protesters without probable cause.

New York City is threatening to do the same, to file a similar suit if agents are sent to New York.

In FBI is accusing China of harboring a fugitive at its San Francisco consulate. The biology researcher at the University of California-Davis now charged with lying about her links to the Chinese military.

Meanwhile, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is demanding the closure of China's consulate in Huston, Texas, to take place tomorrow. This comes after workers there reportedly burned secret documents in the consulate's courtyard. Local reports saw the fires as they burned them.

Now to the coronavirus crisis. Three Midwestern states are now issuing mandatory mask orders. Residents of Indiana, Minnesota and Ohio will be required to cover-up while inside any public or business building. Washington, D.C., also reinforcing its mask policy. Mayor Muriel Bowser signing an executive order which would impose a fine of up to $1,000 for those not wearing a mask in required spots.

And it is opening day today, finally. Major League Baseball begins its 60 game season tonight, leading off with the defending World Series champion Washington Nationals against the New York Yankees, followed by the Los Angeles Dodgers facing off against the rival San Francisco Giants. There will be no fans and -- in the audience and all players will be wearing masks. The league now reportedly discussing plans to expand the playoff field from 10 to 16.

Once football returns, prepare to mask up at NFL games as well. A spokesperson confirming the league's mask policy on Twitter, saying that all fans are required to cover their faces at games this upcoming season.

Well, the biggest SPAC ever. The record-breaking special purpose acquisition company raising four billion dollars via its IPO debuted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Pershing Square Capital Management will also commitment $1.3 billion to this SPAC, bringing total funding to as much as $7 billion to take a potential unicorn public.

Joining me right now is Pershing Square Capital Management CEO and Portfolio Manager Bill Ackman.

Bill, it's great to see you. Thanks so much for being here.

BILL ACKMAN, CEO AND PORTFOLIO MANAGER, PERSHING SQUARE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: It's nice to see you.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations to you. Great performance on you're IPO. Tell us about this approach and whether or not you identified the company you'd like to take public as part of this?

ACKMAN: Sure. So basically what a SPAC is, it's a -- the most simplest IPO in the world. We've raised a tool of cash and our plan is to issue stock from this company and acquire a business where our shareholders end up owning a minority interest in the business. And that's a way to go public in a much more efficient, low risk process.

And because we can do a transaction almost overnight, that enables us to negotiate an attractive price for our investors. And that's the basic plan.

In terms of targets, we want to buy a very large company at $10 billion, $15 billion, $20 billion, $25 billion high quality growth company. And, interestingly, today, there are more such businesses that are private companies than ever before in history. And big part of that is the growth in private equity, growth in venture capital, family owned businesses that have grown in significant size.

BARTIROMO: I know you've said that you're not looking for energy companies that are bankrupt but will certainly look at businesses that will survive the pandemic.

ACKMAN: Do you have a sense of what industry you are -- you're looking toward in terms of what that company is?

ACKMAN: Yes. Energy is really not our thing. We -- we don't like businesses that are exposed to commodity price risk. So we're looking for what we call the super durable growth company, a business that can grow at a relatively high rate for a very longing period of time, but in very high barriers to entry. It's difficult to compete with. And we're looking for the great, you know, long term hold and a business that can compound its value at a high right over a very long periods of time.

BARTIROMO: Where do you see the growth right now, Bill? Obviously, this shutdown has been really troublesome for a lot of industries. Some companies within those industries won't make it out of this, like -- a couple of restaurants and leisure companies.

Where would you find growth right now in terms of industries in this economy?

ACKMAN: So in the short term I totally agree. I mean we're actually big investors in the restaurant industry, a big shareholder of Starbucks, a big shareholder of Restaurant Brands, a big shareholder of Chipotle. You know, so we -- and we're also a large shareholder of Hiltons. We do think each of those businesses, it's still a growth company, but not, you know, the next six, 12 months are going to be a challenging period for companies in that industry.

But our time horizon is much longer. We're looking -- the value of business is it's -- the president value to cash you can take out of that business over its life. And so I do view the pandemic, as troubling and difficult as it is and, you know, obviously everyone wants to go back to a normal existence, I do view it as ultimately temporary in the concept of the life of a strong company, a business that has a balance sheet to withstand this challenging period.

Now, on the other hand, if you're a smaller restaurant or you've got a company with a lot of debt, you know, this is a life-threatening experience for -- for any business in those conditions.

BARTIROMO: So, Bill, what changes because we all remember your infamous interview on another network where you said hell is coming --

ACKMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And you were tweeting at the president saying you've got to shut this economy down completely for 30 days.

ACKMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Now you are saying this is temporary, and so many industries are going to get out of it. So, what changed?

ACKMAN: Nothing changed at all. In fact, that other network took a 15 second excerpt of a 28 minute interview and played it incessantly for days and scared a lot of people. And actually my message was a -- what the message (INAUDIBLE) point, you know, what I said was, we do need to do a hard shutdown, everything other than essential services, for 30 days. And if we do that nationwide and reopen the company carefully, we can minimize the damage to the economy, we can go back to a normal life more quickly, although it will be a life wearing masks until such time as we have, you know, therapeutic drugs that can make this no worse with an flu, or, you know, a vaccine. And that was the message I delivered. Unfortunately, the message was -- it got more of a media reaction by taking a 15 second snippet and, you know, really scaring people. And I really -- what I presented was a what I would call a fork in the road and, as I said in my interview that day, I am buying stocks like Hilton, I'm buying stocks like Starbucks, I'm buying stocks like Restaurant Brands. And it -- that -- that day, for the people who listened to me, that was the low point for Hilton, for Starbucks, for Restaurant Brands, if you actually pull up a chart.

And so I'm a long-term optimist. I think we're going to have a middling (ph) economy for the next, you know, period here. And, you know, I think it's great for the president's, you know, out talking about and wearing a mask. I think it sent an important message. You know, no one likes wearing a mask, but it's better than the alternative. The alternative is, you know, things get out of control and -- and we've seen that happen in -- in some big part of the economy, in Texas, California, Florida.

And so we've -- I think we're going to have to just be -- you know, solve the social distancing rules, wash our hands, wear masks, and then (INAUDIBLE).

The other good news I'll tell you is that businesses are adapting. You know, restaurants are figuring out how to operate, you know, not at the same kind of level they had before. You know, a lot more outdoor dining, a lot more delivery services. You've seen this actually in New York. I was talking to (INAUDIBLE), who's one of the great, you know, chefs in New York. He's got restaurants, you know, the upper end, all the way down to more modest restaurants, and they are adapting. They're figuring out how to operate. And so ingenuity, you know, very American, you know, part of our culture, if you will. And I think ingenuity ultimately will save us. But it's got to be a very challenging period, at least until we get a vaccine.

BARTIROMO: Yes, no, I think you make a lot of good points and there are some industries that are actually seeing their businesses deepen in this. This digital transformation, obviously, gets even more penetrated in all of this.

I want to go through the economy and ask you where you think the structural change will be.

Let's take a short break. Bill, stay with us. We are talking with Bill Ackman this morning after a big IPO in a special purpose deal yesterday. We're going to talk more about that when we come right back.

Stay with us.

Then, stimulus in focus. National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow will join me coming up as well.

Stay with us. More of Bill Ackman when we come right back.

BARTIROMO: Well, welcome back.

We are back with Bill Ackman talking about his special purpose acquisition company and what's happening in markets this morning.

Bill, we were just talking about your comments and you were on the verge of tears, but I want to give you a chance to explain yourself because a week later it was revealed that after you were so negative, hell is coming, you made this huge bet, this short bet against the credit markets and you actually netted $2.6 billion on at $27 million investment and people are saying, well, wait a minute, he came out publicly and said how honorable everything was. Was that in order to make you money?

ACKMAN: Actually not. Actually, we made the 2.6 billion prior -- six days prior to my coming on CNBC. And, actually, I gave a message of optimism. I don't think you're going to replay the 28 minute segment. But if you do, actually, I've got a -- you know, Tucker did a piece about this. I spoke to him subsequently. And I think if you talk to him now he would understand exactly what transpired.

We did opposite. Actually, we made a -- we did hedge our portfolio. We hedged our portfolio to protect our investors, which is our fiduciary obligations. We didn't sell our stocks, actually. That enabled us to benefit from a recovery. And then, after we made a profit, we took the proceeds of the profit and we invested it in stocks. And we were, you know, put in, you know, we're at 3.3 billion more long the market by the time I came on the TV on March 18th. So that's actually what happened.

And I've been -- you know, I'm long-term bullish on the country and my view was, as long as you start shutting down the country, the market will recover. And what happened the day after my appearance on CNBC, California shut down and then the next day New York shut down and then every state in the country effectively --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ACKMAN: Or almost every state went through a shutdown process. And that's why the markets have recovered. And the reason why the markets haven't gone further is because, you know, the reopening has not gone well. You know, states have reopened a little too quickly and that's going to temper economic activity. And so, you know, it's a delicate balance. You know, we can't keep the economy shut forever.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ACKMAN: That's not a good idea. You just have to reopen in a way that's sensible and careful that we don't keep spreading infections. When you spread an infection, it doesn't matter what the government says, people are going to stay home. And if they stay home, they're not going to spend money and the economy's going to falter and more people are going to staying out of work.

And so I'm a huge -- you know, I want the -- you know, life to come back to normal. And if the consequence is we have to wear a mask, for a temporary period of time, it's the right thing for the country. And it -- and, by the way, so my -- you know, I know that narrative is one that --

BARTIROMO: Yes, we're -- we're --

ACKMAN: Yes, go ahead.

BARTIROMO: Well, we're all feeling the same way. I -- I agree with you. I mean this is -- we are living with this now.

Are you surprised to have these soaring market valuations, especially for big tech and -- and health care in an environment where we are in this shutdown? I mean look at Amazon adding $116 billion to its market cap in a single day earlier this week. Look at Tesla.

What do you make of these moves in an environment where you don't have any foot traffic, Bill?

ACKMAN: Yes, look, I -- what's interesting -- I mean Amazon is a certification point. There are certain businesses that are actually huge beneficiaries of this crisis, right? You don't have foot traffic, so you order from home. And a lot of people in the last four months would never use Amazon before have become customers. And once you become a customer, it's actually pretty good -- you know, it's a great service and -- and, you know, so I think there's -- you know, the unfortunate thing is, it's a very big differentiation between the S&P 500, the Nasdaq and real life, right? You know the -- there isn't a stock market index of small business. You know, there isn't an index of the corner grocery store. There isn't an index of the local restaurant. If there were a market index, it would still be down 80 percent.

And so what's happening is the more dominant, well-capitalized companies, like Amazon, the more technologically enabled business, you know, Starbucks, we're a big shareholder, it's a -- you know, they have a great contact list, you know, digital ordering system and they have good deals with the delivery companies, they have a huge advantage over the small -- the small guy. And so I think we can't -- if you're a Wall Street person, you're staying home and you look at the screen and you say, OK, everything's fine, but it is not a fair reflection of what's going on in America. There are a lot of people suffering right now.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And -- and if you don't have a delivery mechanism at the company, whether you're food or, you know, apparel, whatever it is, you're going to get left behind because, you're right, that's the mode of shopping and spending money right now.

I want to get your take on Tesla, Bill, because the stock is soaring in the pre-market. It's up 280 percent this year. The company did report a fourth quarter of profits, meaning that it possibly could be eligible for inclusion in the S&P 500. But my sources are telling me that part of the -- the boost there in earnings was because the company has deferred rent payments.

ACKMAN: You know, the --

BARTIROMO: My sources say that Elon Musk tried to defer rent in at least -- in several of his properties and one New York landlord said, no, no, no, we cannot defer, but he did it anyway and he only paid half of the rent, $700,000 a month, Bill, for four month.

ACKMAN: Yes. So, first of all, I actually have a point of view on that. I think companies with, you know, hundreds of billions of dollars in market caps should not be deferring the payment of rent. You know, landlords, you know, their -- their mortgage have to be paid on time, you know, so, you know, yes, if you're a small business you can't afford to pay rent. That's where you are. If you're Tesla, you can.

Now, from an accounting standpoint, I don't think your sources are correct. Even if you were to defer rent from a GAAP profitability point of view, which is what the S&P will look at, you know, in terms of whether a company's eligible for inclusion in an index, even if you don't pay the rent, you have to expense it from a GAAP perspective, and that -- that wouldn't enable Tesla to make, you know, the threshold (ph).

Look, I think -- I do think Tesla is a great company. I bought a Tesla SUV Model X recently. You know, it's a great car. It's a, you know, very differentiated car. You know, whether the valuation is correct here or not, you know, I don't know. I've not, you know, I've not done the work on Tesla. You know, the market's obviously expecting them to take enormous market share. But they very well may do so because their cars are, you know, becoming much more ubiquitous, but they've sill -- you know, they're a tiny percentage of the market and they have a better quality -- better product than -- than many alternatives.

On this new pickup, I think, is going to go, you know, extremely, extremely well. And, you know, Tesla -- you know, the auto -- the big auto companies are so far behind. So it's not crazy to me --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ACKMAN: That the company -- its stock is going up.

BARTIROMO: I --

ACKMAN: I just don't know whether today's valuation is a reasonable reflection of a, you know, ultimately how much cash the business will generate over time.

BARTIROMO: When you say the sources are not right, he didn't pay the rent. So, that we know.

ACKMAN: No, no, no, I don't know -- I don't know about them not paying the rent. I -- I -- what I'm saying is --

BARTIROMO: What -- what are you saying, in other words, the speculation that it is because he was going to join the S&P 500? What are you saying?

ACKMAN: No, what I'm saying is the way -- I'm a, you know, an accounting person also and even if you're -- if you're a company that has a rent expense, whether you pay it or not --

BARTIROMO: OK.

ACKMAN: It comes out of the profits of the company. You know, GAAP accounting --

BARTIROMO: OK.

ACKMAN: You know, simply because you defer the payment --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ACKMAN: It's not going to increase your profit. So that part is the part I disagree with. Whether he paid --

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Self-censorship in America as many on both sides of the aisle debate and discuss the 2020 presidential election, a new survey from the Cato Institute finds 26 percent of Americans hold police beliefs they're afraid to express fearing that they may offend others. The survey also finds Republicans are more cautious than Democrats about expressing their views. The Cato Institute says self-censorship has risen during the Trump administration.

These are interesting numbers. And, Dagen, I think this may explain some of the polls out there.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: If you voted for Trump you're going to get called a Nazi or a racist or even worse than that, particularly if you work within a progressive company. People are afraid of losing their jobs. That's where we are in this nation and it's disgraceful.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, it's because of the mobs, Gianno. The mobs will come at you if they don't -- if they don't agree with you.

GIANNO CALDWELL, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: One hundred percent. One hundred percent. And just to see this poll shows that it favors Trump in November because the only political things that are unpopular are those that favor Trump. So you should feel very happy about what we're seeing here.

BARTIROMO: All right, a quick break, and then we've got the initial jobless claims after this break. We want to get that economic data coming up. It could move markets.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 23rd.

We are breaking news in moments. Another look at the impact the coronavirus is having on jobs and the economy when initial jobless claims will be released in about 15 seconds.

Economists are expecting another 1.3 million people filed for unemployment benefits last week. Since the lockdowns began in mid-March, over 51 million people have filed for unemployment claims.

Ahead of the numbers this morning, futures are higher. Dow futures right now at the highs of the morning, up 82 points, the Nasdaq futures up 68, and the S&P futures right now up 7.75 points.

We are looking at money moving to stocks because of better-than-expected earnings partly and also some optimism over a vaccine. We told you yesterday about the deal that HHS has done with Pfizer where they will have 100 million doses of a vaccine.

Let's get right to Jackie DeAngelis. She's got the initial jobless claims numbers right now.

Jackie.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria.

Initial jobless claims for the week ended July 18th, 1.416 million. That is higher than the 1.3 million that was expected and higher than the prior week's 1.3 million as well. It does break the 15 week stretch of declines we had been seeing. The peak, of course, 6.9 million at the end of March. And as you mentioned, more than 52 million people now have filed jobless claims.

Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Wow, these numbers are not good.

Thank you so much, Jackie DeAngelis.

The market has not moved much on numbers.

Mark Tepper, your reaction?

MARK TEPPER, PRESIDENT AND CEO, STRATEGIC WEALTH PARTNERS: Yes, I mean it's disappointing that we're still so high when it comes to initial jobless claims. I mean the economy is supposed to be in rebound mode, but at the same point in time, a lot of these governors are starting to scale back their reopenings. So, I mean, that could be causing some of these issues.

But -- but, nonetheless, it's still high. I mean when we're talking -- any -- any time we're over a million, nowadays, I mean back in the day it was, you know, a few hundred thousand. But any time we're over a million it's a problem.

I mean I guess the silver lining here is continuing claims have come down a little bit. So, you know, it does look like we -- we do have some people going back to work. Whether or not they are going to be permanent placements and they're permanently going back to work, that's another story and we need to look a little deeper at that. But it is disappointing that initial jobless claims remain so high.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we are looking at a market that I guess is getting used to this at this point, Dagen. You've got the Dow up this morning 74 points. Not a major reaction. It was -- yes, it was worse than expected, but my -- not by much. These are sort of in the neighborhood of what we were looking for.

MCDOWELL: The continuing claims. These are people who are -- have -- who are still on unemployment, came in below expectations, 16.197. Again, still really high, but that is below the estimate of nearly 17.1 million.

Since the coronavirus shutdowns, roughly one-third of the American labor force has had to file unemployment benefits at any time.

But this market is also reacting to a Congress that is going to act with more stimulus money, maybe a trillion dollars. Step up with -- certainly extending all or some of the extra $600 per week in unemployment benefits, but also more aid to individuals, maybe more checks. So the government, the White House, they're standing by at the ready to support this economy that has yet to reopen yet. But by the end of this year, we likely will have a virus or -- not virus, a vaccine or vaccines ready, and through regulatory approval. So there's a lot of optimism because of that.

BARTIROMO: All right, joining me right now to talk more about this is National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow.

Larry, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

LARRY KUDLOW, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL: Thank you, Maria. Appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: I want -- I want to get your reaction to these jobless claims this morning. The last time we spoke you said that you were going to -- you and your team were going to reassess where we are because initially, you were looking for a 20 percent second half in terms of growth.

Where are we today, Larry?

KUDLOW: Well, it's still a 20 percent second half, still on the V-shaped recovery camp (ph). The jobless claims today, yes, initial claims off a bit. The four week average, smooth average, which is what people tend to look at, continues to decline, I don't know, the (ph) 15 or 16 straight months. Continuing claims, which may be more important for unemployment, actually fell a huge 1.1 million. So I don't see any breaking of the downward trend for unemployment and the upper trend for job creation. We're -- we're reasonably optimistic about July.

I do want to say, though, in general, when you look at the whole panoply of economic series and data, you've basically got a housing boom going on. There's an automobile boom. Both sales and production going on. Manufacturing is surging from the ISM reports, as you can see, including the regional Federal Reserve Bank reports. And that's a pretty good mix. Retail sales are very strong and business applications are strong.

I know we have an issue here, which we've talked about, and it's hard to predict but the southwest problems, the flare-ups of the virus in the southwest are still difficult. There are some modest signs of improvement. For example, Arizona has flattened out considerably. Still trouble in Texas and California. And I will acknowledge, large trouble in the Miami-Dade County, Florida, area.

But all that said, I don't see any evidence yet -- maybe there will be a moderation of the numbers in July, but I don't see any evidence of economic harm. I'm just looking at these key sectors that are booming. I would add to that, by the way, inventories at rock-bottom. So I still think we're in a self-sustaining recovery.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're -- we're looking at a market that is given up stuff - - some -- much of the rally this morning, struggling to hold on to gains on the heels of these numbers. And you're looking at Washington, the White House, yourself included, obviously, with Congress trying to come up with new ideas for the next coronavirus relief program.

What about these unemployed Americans, the unemployment benefits expiring next week, Larry? Republican aides say that a two-month extension of the unemployment aid expansion is being considered. Do you want to see that?

KUDLOW: No. The White House is not there yet. The president's not there yet. We know there's expiration. We suggest that we make a deal as promptly as possible. We do not wish to extend the unemployment benefits of the $600 federal plus-up, simply because basic economics show that if the benefits are significantly higher than the wages, people are not going to go back to work and we don't want to pay them not to work, we want to get them back to work. In fact, the mantra that we are talking with Senator Mitch McConnell and the leadership is, you know, kids and jobs, kids and jobs.

Now we have decided and agreed to a significant boost in the education funding. Half of it on a per pupil basis, half of it going to safety reopening measures because we very, very much want schools to reopen, which is healthier and safer for the kids in school according to a number of experts.

We would like to change unemployment to roughly a cap of 70 percent of wages. And on top of that, we have incentives. We're going to put a reemployment bonus or tax credit on of a significant amount.

And, don't forget, the president still supports a payroll tax cut, a payroll tax holiday, which would plus up after tax wages by roughly 7.5 percent. That's an inducement to come back to work. If you tax employment less, you'll get more employment. And that's the goal here, kids and jobs.

BARTIROMO: Well, Larry, what about doing middle of the ground in terms of the unemployment benefits? Are you considering half of that number, $300, or some form of the unemployment benefit to extend, but not the full 600?

KUDLOW: What I -- I'm not going to negotiate this on air, much as I might like to, you and I could probably solve this in a nanosecond. But we're -- we're not -- we're not going to negotiate this morning.

I will add to this, though. I mean I think we're going to come to agreement, frankly, and we'll see if the Democrats want to abide by that agreement. I think that's coming. I'm always the optimist.

I will add, liability protection, you know, for small businesses, for schools, for hospitals, for health care and so forth, that's a key element of this package. I don't know why Democrats are opposed to it. It makes a lot of sense. We don't want the trial bar to block economic recovery and folks going back to work or folks, you know, kids going back to school. So that's another key part of the program. Senator McConnell insists on it and President Trump wholly agrees.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let -- let me ask you about -- about growth and where it comes from, Larry. I know some industries are going to see real structural change. What do you think will be the growth industries that will take us out of that, will -- that will lead to that 20 percent second half?

KUDLOW: Well, you know, not being an expert in all those matters, but I -- I would suggest this. Pharmaceuticals, medicines, therapies, vaccines, and technology. Biotechnology is going to be one. You know, right now -- I was at the virus task force meeting yesterday afternoon for Vice President Pence and his group. They're increasingly optimistic about vaccines. And in at least one case, at least one case, there's, I think, three leading cases, at least one of them's going into phase three testing. There may be another one, I'm not sure. I'm not an expert there. But we're really moving at warp speed. Nobody's ever seen development of a new vaccine at this speed.

And I think, you know, in terms of future industries, Maria, whether it's therapies, medicines, vaccines and related matters, all kinds of equipment and so forth, hospital equipment and improvements, I think that's going to be a very great -- I mean it has -- always has been. America has the number one pharmaceutical biotech by far.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: So I think that's going to be there.

And I think all things technology, you know, that's what the stock market's been telling you.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: You've got this gigantic, what, we're up 45 percent from the lows of last March. I think the S&P -- I know the Nasdaq is already in -- in plus column for year-to-date. So I like tech and biotech. You know, that's where I think the future goes. But -- but, but, but, let me just add, because of our trade deals, particularly the USMCA, but also the China trade deals, I believe manufacturing is going to have a tremendous comeback. I think we've already seen that in some of the numbers.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: And I think our great farming sector, our agriculture sector, is going to show a big comeback. So, I'm optimistic about the American economy, low taxes, deregulation, fair and reciprocal trade deals, energy independence. The president will build on those successes that he had for three and a half years into his second term and I think it's going to be a booster for the entire economy. I'm looking for a strong second half and a good 2021.

BARTIROMO: And -- and -- Larry -- Larry, you -- you mentioned the -- the money being considered in terms -- in terms of this next relief package. I know the president has talked a lot about testing. There is going to be money allocated for testing, correct? And -- and let me ask you, if you're not getting to some of the things that you want to get to in this package, will there be a fifth relief package?

KUDLOW: Well, that's a very good point. And, you know, I don't want to forecast the legislative process, but I think if it turns out -- look, the -- the target here, as you know, is about a trillion dollars. If that is insufficient for some reason, all right, perhaps the -- the pandemic continues to flare up, we -- we're going to put in more PPP money, payroll protection Monday for small businesses, I think you probably know. But we can come back and pass additional funding. I mean we've set up a terrific infrastructure for that between the SBA and the Treasury and the Federal Reserve and other agencies. So we -- we can get that done if we need to get it done.

But let me just stay, my mantra here is just so darn important. If you want the economy to reopen, if you want kids to go back to school, if you want folks to go back to work and create new employment, new jobs, and lower the unemployment rate, the five major -- the four major points, Maria, masking, distancing, testing, and good, clean hygiene, all right? It's so simple to me.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: You've heard the president say this in his recent press conferences. Everybody is on board. Masking, distancing, testing and good personal hygiene will keep the virus down, allow folks to go back to work - -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLOW: Allow kids to go back to school. That is the key. We are going to keep up our pro-market supply-side economic policies to liberate business and reward success. That's the president's pledge.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Larry, it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

KUDLOW: Thanks, Maria. Appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Larry Kudlow. Have a great day, sir. Thank you very much, Larry.

We'll be right back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Finding beauty in destruction. Visual arts Jan Erichsen is make things like balloon popping, pasta smashing and much more into an art form. He took something he did for fun in his art studio and turned it into a widely particular Instagram account.

Joining me right now is visual artist and balloon destroyer Jan Erichsen.

Jan, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

JAN HAKON ERICHSEN, VISUAL ARTIST: (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: And congratulations for turning this into a business.

How did you first start doing these videos? What -- tell me about how you got started.

ERICHSEN: As you said, it was just for fun in the beginning. It was just me fooling around in my studio, really, and then I just decided to post them online just to share with a few friends I had on my Instagram account. So it's just like a hundred followers at the time. Then it just started escalating from there. So, yes.

BARTIROMO: Very, very cool.

And you have been able to expand your brand. How do you make money from this page?

ERICHSEN: I mean it's not that big of a business, but I do collaboration with brands and sometimes they use my videos for their advertisements and like that then and then I make money. And then also I do -- like custom radios for customers sometimes.

BARTIROMO: But you've transitioned from displaying your art in galleries to doing it all on social media, right?

ERICHSEN: Yes. I rarely do gallery shows now. Before I just did gallery shoes and radio festivals and that was all I did. And then after I started posting online, it was a lot more rewarding just to -- to do that, because I get so many views and so much response. I mean when we have gallery shows, people almost don't talk to you because like, you know, some people come up and say good show but you don't really get any response. And then maybe like half a year till next time. But now I get an outlet for my art every day on social media and such much more rewarding experience.

BARTIROMO: Very cool. So tell me how it's done. How -- how tough is it to get the -- the products to put the art together? Walk us through the process of how you -- how you've done it.

ERICHSEN: I mean I used to just use every day materials that they -- you can just get at your local supermarket, like balloons and spaghetti and things like that. And I usually just start with the materials. I -- one day I'll decide I want to do -- work with balloons and then I just start thinking, OK, what can I do with a balloons today that I haven't done before and then decide on some object to story the -- and then it just kind of escalates from there. And when I had one idea, usually I -- it feeds over to another video. So it kind of -- I don't have to think that much about it, I just have to work and keep on doing it and then kind of ideas come by themselves. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Amazing, really. Such entrepreneurialism and -- and creativity.

Jan, thank you. Thanks for being here. Congrats on being an Instagram star.

Jan Erichsen joining us there.

ERICHSEN: Yes, thank you. Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: A quick break.

One university might be going -- and to you.

One university might be going a little too far. The public school that's requiring a specific class to be taken before students can graduate. It is causing quite the controversy.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

California State University is now requiring its students to take courses on ethnic studies and social justice in order to graduate. The board of trustee approved the proposal yesterday saying that students now have to take three units worth of classes on race and other social issues. It will start in the 2021-2022 school year.

Your reaction, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Not uncommon for some schools to require certain coursework. At Wake Forest, I was required to get my diploma to study religion. I studied Hebrew. And I will point out that California law actually requires state officials to complete an ethics training course within the first six months of being hired. This is -- given the movement in the country, this isn't that surprising.

BARTIROMO: Mark Tepper?

TEPPER: Yes, so, likewise, I had to do this 20 years ago at John Carroll University. We had to take at least one course on either Asian or African studies to graduate. I've never seen this at a state school though. Do I think this requirement is going to make the world a measurably better place? No, I don't. You know, quite frankly, I'm just not one who believes that forcing people to do things works very well. I think you end up with a lot of resentment, noncompliance and people end up revolting.

BARTIROMO: But then again they get the exposure to it, Gianno. What do you think?

Gianno Caldwell?

All right, we -- we are -- we are waiting on -- on --

TEPPER (ph): Yes, so -- so, yes, I mean they -- you know they definitely --

BARTIROMO: Yes, go ahead, Gianno.

Go ahead, Mark.

TEPPER: All right, yes, so, that -- I forget -- I forget what your question is. But, look, I mean this right now, this is kind of right in the wheelhouse of what a lot of people's criticisms are with regards to colleges, college tuition, all that stuff. I mean colleges force to you take so many classes that you don't need to keep you there for four years and then -- then students are racking up these large tuition bills, they're trying to get all of the taxpayers to pay those tuition bills off for them, you know? And even recently, President Trump, he recently signed an executive order favoring experience all of a sudden over education. So, look, I think the shift is happening with regard to colleges.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right.

Gianno, you with us?

All right, we'll take a short break.

When we come back, we will hear from Gianno Caldwell.

More MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business right after this.

BARTIROMO: All right, welcome back.

We are expecting a decline at the start of trading now. Things have completely reversed course on the heels of those jobless claims. Dow Industrials poised to (ph) open down about 40 points.

Thanks to this great panel, Dagen McDowell, Mark Tepper, Gianno Caldwell. Great to see you all.

MCDOWELL: Great to see you.

CALDWELL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: And have a great day everybody. Seize the day.
