Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5C2M-0CY1-JD2T-F12W-00000-00Bill Ackman's Latest Move and Discussion of Insider Trading;[1]2014-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill Ackman's Latest Move and Discussion of Insider Trading[1]

MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: We have a lot lined up. In fact the secret is out. Bill Ackman refusing to back down from his billion dollar bet against Herbalife. He's even paying insiders millions to dish some dirt. Two tech giants in two big reports. The burning questions Facebook and Apple finally need to answer as they announce their latest results. And some new voices in the fight against Keystone. We're live from the capital as so-called cowboy and Indian activists march on D.C. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

On the heels of the bid to buy Allergan, activist investor Bill Ackman is heeding the headlines again. A new report. So the hedge fund titan is agreeing to spend up to $3.6 million to an Herbalife whistleblower. Here to discuss all that, Charlie Gasparino, James Freeman of "Wall Street Journal" and Ken Mahoney of Mahoney Asset Management. We couldn't stop talking about it even before the show started. He is skating very close to the line here on a number of different bets. Let's talk about Herbalife first. I mean what do you think about paying this whistle-blower?

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: You know, he has a rationale for it, which I saw in the ABC News piece, Brian Ross and another gentleman from ABC News wrote the story. It is online. The rationale that it's, you know, perfectly OK to pay for whistleblower's legal costs and whatever.

FRANCIS: I mean it was - they are going to pay him $250,000 a year for lost work due to whistleblowing, even though he is working, I guess, in a laundromat. So far he's made $80,000. He denied that in the past. But he said, technically he hadn't received the funds yet, so he wasn't lying.

GASPARINO: I want to say this. As someone who has covered these sort of stories, whistleblowers and hedge funds and, you know activist investors, I've never seen people pay off people like this before. This - unless I'm missing something.

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: And why do they have to? I mean .

GASPARINO: I agree.

FREEMAN: If this is such an obvious pyramid scheme, why does Ackman have to spend all the money on lawyering and lobbying and PR to convince people? Federal regulators have information on this company for a long time now. Why this constant campaign?

GASPARINO: And it's not like ..

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Really is a pyramid.

GASPARINO: And it's not like.

FREEMAN: That's what I'm saying - it's not, but it's out there.

GASPARINO: But it's not - and it's not like Bernie Madoff, well, as you see. People keep saying this might be like Bernie Madoff when people looked at him. Bernie Madoff was barely in the news when this stuff was going on.

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: There were a few investigations. This guy is in the news every day.

KEN MAHONEY, MAHONEY ASSET MANAGEMENT: And this one investors are looking at all the time. Because, you know, they say it is not a level playing field. They say that is rigged. You know, these types of stories, you know, shine a spotlight. Wait a second, average investor is not doing these types of things. And look, they call it a gray area, but I think it kind of pushes .

GASPARINO: What you're talking about is how he invested in Allergan, which we were first to report yesterday.

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: You look at CNBC today. That is all they're talking about.

FRANCIS: Not familiar with that channel.

GASPARINO: Right. Not either.

(LAUGHTER)

GASPARINO: But I know - I can't help it. It is in the newsroom. And - but what is interesting is the notion that Bill Ackman can go, be told by a partner..

FRANCIS: You are talking about Allergan?

GASPARINO: Yeah, the Allergan. By Valiant that he was going to make a bid for Allergan. Join me in this bid. Go in undercover, buy options, so it's not seen by anybody. The market doesn't notice. And low and behold, guess what happens? They put the bid in, the market goes up and you make a lot of money. Now, does this violate insider trading laws? No. But if you want to know what gets people mad, more than high frequency trading, this looks pretty - this is a perfect example of why the playing field is unlevel ..

(CROSSTALK)

GASPARINO: By the way - completely illegal.

MAHONEY: How he got the information? You know, it was (INAUDIBLE) flying over his head and drop the note on him and told him this is going on?

FRANCIS: Right.

MAHONEY: You know, individual investors don't get their uncle and tell them this is going on. So .

FRANCIS: And it's interesting - it's interesting that Ackman wears the cap of I'm the activist investor. So, out there for the little guy. You know, I represent the voice of a little guy.

(CROSSTALK)

MAHONEY: There are current investors in those funds.

FRANCIS: That's what activist investors have been saying. But that is not really what it is about. He is the super investor who has the inside track on all the information. And he is part of the problem that we've seen such an unleveled playing field. Some would say, do you agree with that? Do you guys agree with that?

FREEMAN: Two very different situations. On the Herbalife thing I think Ackman's paying a lot of money to gin up federal investigations - and it smells pretty bad. With this situation, when, you know, Valiant and Allergan, I see nothing wrong here. I mean I think it - federal judges, if you look at - as they're deliberating now in Manhattan about what is the limit of insider trading .

GASPARINO: I would say this.

FREEMAN: Their questions are suggesting this is not insider trading.

GASPARINO: I would say - I would say this. I'm against the insider trading laws. I think we should throw them just - right off the bat.

FREEMAN: All right.

GASPARINO: That said, if you are going to have them, this is just how rich people can keep getting rich. There is no way the average guy in the street is ever going to get a tip from Valiant, oh, go buy some stock and join me and buying three options and you let's - and you can make a lot of money.

FRANCIS: It is not going to happen.

MAHONEY: Look, it is not illegal, the way we look at it. But it is not morally or ethically the way to do business. And that's kind of what's coming back, and that's why - I was looking out there.

FRANCIS: It's about - yeah, and it's about the rich getting richer, which is why people are shying away from the stock market. And it's a shame because stock prices are up 175 percent from the bottom. And it is an opportunity for the average person to make money, but they are scared .

FREEMAN: Well, the average person - better prices.

FRANCIS: Hang on. More to discuss after this. Don't move. Don't move.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Moving on now to Amazon. The online retail giant has a new licensing agreement with HBO. Prime members can now get subscription access to content like "The Sopranos" and "Girls." Shareholders, however, not loving this so far. You don't like - Let's go to James Romelli down at the CME. James, what do you think about this? How is it trading?

JAMES ROMELLI: Right. You know, this is a groundbreaking deal in terms of HBO is not going to be offered on Amazon's prime subscription service. And this is first time it is being offered on any streaming subscription based service. However, it's not a very big deal for Amazon. And if we look at the stock price today, it is down around $5. So, it is clear that investors really are not excited over this deal. I think if we take a look at this it's really more of a negative for companies like Netflix than it is a positive for a company like Amazon.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

ROMELLI: It does show that they are going to be willing to go out there and acquire premium content. They have much deeper pockets than Netflix. They're a much larger company. And Netflix does not want them in this space. It shows they're serious about growing that part of their business and they are going to be aggressive about it.

FRANCIS: James, real quick, before you go - what's the feel in the market today? I'm looking at a Dow, that's down 14 points.

FREEMAN: Right. So, we are looking at a market that's down run 14 points. Most of the moves are higher this week. We're on very thin volume. We're still trading pretty thinly holiday week. I say earnings have been pretty good. I think the markets going ahead higher into the end of the week. And I think next week, once the traders are back from holiday we really see a sustained move higher on volume.

FRANCIS: All right, James, thanks so much. Soon, a new report shows that America no longer has the world's wealthiest middle class. That honor now goes to Canada. We can thank the small growth in the U.S. middle incomes compared to other nations. There are still some good news for the red, white and blue, with recent gains to high-end households the U.S. continues to rein as the world's richest large country. Let's bring the panel back. The divide just grows wider.

GASPARINO: Yeah, and I would say, one reason why it is, is kind of what we were going to get into before.

FRANCIS: Yes.

GASPARINO: You know - you know, (INAUDIBLE) and all these regulators scaring people out of the stock market, saying, oh, it is rig, high frequency trading, insider trading. Do you realize all you had to do is buy an S&P 500 index, put $1,000 in and that, in 2009 when they started easing, when they started printing money? But you make a lot of money. I mean markets are not rigged if you play it safe and not try to compete with these big guys on insider (INAUDIBLE). I think, you know, they should just legalize insider information. Legalize high frequency trading. And guess what? Small investors should buy index funds.

FRANCIS: Do you guys agree with that idea?

MAHONEY: It's - insider trading? No, I think you need to have insider trading rules. And again, it's hard to define what those rules are going to be.

GASPARINO: That's why we shouldn't have them.

(LAUGHTER)

MAHONEY: Yeah, I mean, look. This is the market for small investors also. Look, this is the market is like the energizer bunny, right? It keeps going and going and going. Interest rates are low. Earnings have been pretty good the last couple of years. So, if you kind of stay the course .

FRANCIS: But that's what that stat tells you. I mean that middle income folks are falling further and further behind. That the policies we've seen over the past five years have done nothing but enrich the one percent.

GASPARINO: Well, that's another story.

MAHONEY: That's another story.

FREEMAN: We want to get more of those middle income people to become capitalists. To raise their incomes to the point where they can own stocks, where they can benefit. Now, how do you do that? You notice Canada on that list has been very friendly, much more than the United States to energy production in its west.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: We have an energy boom pretty much despite Washington.

GASPARINO: Right.

GASPARINO: Welders making over $200,000 a year in some cases in Ohio. And we ought to be encouraging that.

FRANCIS: Real quick, before we go, Ken, do you agree with the idea that the policies of the past five years have done nothing but made the divide bigger?

MAHONEY: I think so. The unintended consequences of Obamacare, we are seeing how wage stagnation, you know, hiring of employees.

FRANCIS: And the Fed juicing the stock market as the number one .

(CROSSTALK)

GASPARINO: Melissa, think of it this way, if you have manufacture jobs going overseas, blue-collar jobs overseas, why not do Keystone pipeline? Why not do fracking? Those are blue color ..

FRANCIS: We have some folks that are going to come up with.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Coming up, tech heavyweights take center stage. The market holding its breath for Facebook an Apple earnings. We have got the answer to all of your burning questions coming up.

And we haven't seen this much cooperation since the first Thanksgiving. Cowboys and Indians teaming up to stop the Keystone pipeline. We are live at the protests. Teepees tents and bonfires included.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it is on Wall Street or Main Street here is who is making and losing money today. Anyone with a piece of Netflix. The stock sinking today following news of Amazon's content deal with HBO. Shares are down more than five percent right now. That is bad news for CEO Reed Hastings. He has nearly 2 1/2 million shares. So he is less $48 million today. That hurts. And speaking of the Amazon, someone over there is losing even more money. CEO Jeff Bezos. His net worth has taken a real dive this year, already losing more than 6 billion bucks. Out of all the people on the planet Earth, Bezos is second only to Carlos Slim who's lost around $6.5 billion so far in 2014. What a rough year. You know, I'm sure they're both crying in their Benjamins. But you know who is about to save a whole lot of money on cheap and vast fashion? All of us here in the U.S. Highmart (ph), which is one of Europe's most successful clothing chains is landing on our shores. It's going to challenge other retailers with these rock-bottom prices. It has even been known to offer a pair of jeans for less than ten bucks. I bet they don't shrink. The first store will open in Boston within a year.

All right, anticipation is rising for Apple and Facebook earnings after the bell today. Stocks are slipping. So can this report ease investor fears and answer the burning questions? Adam Lashinsky, is "Fortune" magazine senior editor at large and the Fox News contributor, Ari Zoldan is Quantum Network CEO and Lance Ulanoff, is Mashable editor-at-large. Adam, I don't think I have ever seen you in person. You have legs.

(LAUGHTER)

ADAM LASHINSKY, FORTUNE MAGAZINE SENIOR EDITOR-AT-LARGE: I hope so.

FRANCIS: I've always seen you on the remote. Yes. I will start with you since you're in town. For Apple you want to know when and not what. When will they release their next major category? What category do you think it is?

LASHINSKY: Well .

FRANCIS: You just don't care? You just want to know when it's going to happen.

LASHINSKY: Right. It's - to me as an investor, as somebody watching company, it doesn't matter what it is. It could be a television. It could be the whole living room. It could be, you know, it can't be a watch. That's not enough. The point is they need something of the magnitude of the IPod, the iPhone and the iPad for this company to take the next leap forward. Anything else is gravy.

FRANCIS: So, you want them to say when.

LASHINSKY: I want them to.

FRANCIS: Because I mean this is the question.

LASHINSKY: By the way they won't today.

FRANCIS: They are not going to do it. They are not going to do it. They don't care what you want. All right.

LASHINSKY: Oh, no that's for sure.

FRANCIS: On Apple, you want to know what other markets are on their radar besides China. Why?

ARI ZOLDAN, QUANTUM NETWORKS & CEO: Right. China was - I mean they have done a great job in China. I would imagine right now if I were to take a guess it's probably going to be Latin America.

FRANCIS: Yes.

ZOLDAN: Just, you know, looking at the demographic and the numbers and the size of it - I mean it's an extraordinary market for Apple to break into.

FRANCIS: Do you agree with that, Lance? You're shaking your head.

LANCE ULANOFF, MASHABLE EDITOR-AT-LARGE: Oh, yeah. I mean it's sort of like we forget about these other parts of the world, like Brazil, this vibrant social media community, these products there, and services that we don't even know about in the U.S. So, of course you want to go in their place. And that means they are connected and they want to hear.

LASHINSKY: And by the way, Apple has said quite a bit about that. Their growth outside of the United States and Europe is much faster than it is .

ZOLDAN: And there is lot of brand loyalty - there's a lot of brand loyal to also within the Latin American market.

FRANCIS: Lance, for Apple, you want to know, I mean they're hesitating on the wearables front. What is behind that? Should they get into that? What is your question with that?

ULANOFF: You know, Apple is smart about products. They are going carefully. They are going when they're ready and I think they are looking around now and I don't know if they're getting cold feet. Obviously, Nike just laid off a bunch of people work in their wearable division. I'm looking at everybody's wrist here and I don't see any wearable devices.

FRANCIS: No.

ULANOFF: And, by the way, that is not unusual. And I think Apple is, you know, they sometimes like to lead, but they are really - they are not quite getting it, right, all the people they've hired, all the designers, all the help - I think they're still working on it. I'm waiting for a signal today that tells us what might happen over the next few months.

FRANCIS: They could be the one to revolutionize that space if they get into it. Because there has been so many of those little fit wristlets and you see people wear them. Just love them .

ZOLDAN: But they're not leaders anymore. But Melissa - but they're not leaders anymore. You know.

FRANCIS: Apple is?

ZOLDAN: Yeah, Apple is .

FRANCIS: Really?

ZOLDAN: Apple is not leaders anymore.

LASHINSKY: Let me just correct you on that.

ZOLDAN: Not anymore.

LASHINSKY: The interesting thing on this - they never have been. They didn't have the first music player. They didn't have the first smartphone. And they didn't have the .

(CROSSTALK)

ULANOFF: But they did have one's market share. But they did have market share and they did have a brand followings. Right? Isn't that really what we want to talk about? It's not that they are leaders. They're innovators.

(CROSSTALK)

ZOLDAN: Makes total sense they have not (INAUDIBLE) the wearables yet.

ULANOFF: Exactly. They will wait for everybody to fall over on themselves.

FRANCIS: Let's move on to Facebook. Adam, you want to know when Sheryl Sandberg is leaving.

LASHINSKY: Yes.

FRANCIS: I mean we've see all the signals. It seems like with the whole lean in launch - it feels like a political campaign.

LASHINSKY: Yes.

FRANCIS: It does. She sold a lot of stock.

LASHINSKY: Yes.

FRANCIS: It feels like she has kind of done that and is on her way out.

LASHINSKY: Sure. So, Sheryl Sandberg is a natural politician.

FRANCIS: Yes.

LASHINSKY: If you listen to her five minutes you know that. So, you see this public profile. Yes, it feels like her work is done there and someone else could do her job. And furthermore, that she has other things that she would like to do. So yes, I think it is important eventually that Facebook say, what is the schedule for Sheryl?

FRANCIS: You're shaking your head. You agree with that?

ULANOFF: Yeah, yeah, I think so. I mean I read her whole book. I think, you know, she has got a lot on her mind. She wants to lead women in particular and but I don't think she will jump right into political office. I think she'll work for some - maybe she'll work for an administration first.

FRANCIS: You think? I don't know. I mean there's been talk about her running for Barbara Boxer's seat, running in California. She has such a strong base there. You don't think ..

(CROSSTALK)

ZOLDAN: I think she will. She's on the whole Facebook.

FRANCIS: She's - yeah.

ZOLDAN: She's been there done that. That's for her I think is a natural.

ULANOFF: You'll have to answer that full disparity question in Silicon Valley.

FRANCIS: And one last question, Lance. You want to know on Facebook, how important is that that consumers realize that WhatsApp are Facebook products. WhatsApp and Instagram. Why is that important? Why is that the answer you need?

ULANOFF: Well, I just think that what surprised a little bit is how Facebook has not sort of sucked them all the way in and rebranded them.

FRANCIS: Maybe because it's - Facebook is not cool anymore and WhatsApp is?

ULANOFF: Well, I think there is part of that. But it's also being smart. The way they look at the business going forward, is a number of satellite businesses. They want to be a conglomerate. They want to be more like a unilever. And so, Facebook becomes the hub and all these other products live outside of each other.

FRANCIS: You guys are so smart. We are going to leave it there. Thanks to all three of you.

LASHINSKY: Thank you.

FRANCIS: Coming up, the very local issue that has international celebs crying out loud. Horses have long been a mainstay in New York Central Park. We're going to show you this very green innovation that could be coming to your town too.

Plus, big tech names are taking over New York. Some on Wall Street are starting, to get very nervous. Do you ever have too much money?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Wireless carrier AT&T narrowly beating first-quarter earnings, really dropping today. Let's go to Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange. Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: It's a name that we've been watching so closely today, Melissa. It is been the big loser on the Dow Jones industrial average. Right now it is down 3.6 percent for AT&T at 34.99. It has been ticking down some of the names in the telecom sector, including Verizon, CenturyLink, Windstream as well as Frontier communication. You've had several of the analysts putting their comments out. And JPMorgan, for example, cut their price target to $34 from 35. They have a neutral rating. So, they did come out with their numbers. They've raised their full-year revenue growth forecast. AT&T, to at least four percent from three percent. But the big picture here, is that the overall numbers from AT&T were disappointing to Wall Street. And as a result we're seeing that name to the downside. Back to you.

FRANCIS: Nicole, thanks so much. So, one of New York City's most popular attractions may be heading back to the stables. The idea of retiring Central Park's horse-drawn carriages, has drawn both the ire and the praise of many of celebrities since Mayor Bill de Blasio voiced that idea. It includes Liam Neeson, Alec Baldwin, singer Pink and former mayor Michael Bloomberg, all on different sides. No one company - now one company is trotting along with a very unique innovation, an all-electric vintage automobile. It is classy and green enough to replace the beloved horses they believe.

Joining us now is Creative Workshop owner Jason Wenig. So walk me through this. Mayor Bill de Blasio reached out to you about this?

JASON WENIG, CREATIVE WORKSHOP OWNER: No. Several years ago, Niclass (ph). It is the group that's on the forefront of this change approached me asking me what I would do about the idea of replacing the carriages. And that is how the whole thing started.

FRANCIS: OK, what are the carriages like? Walk me through it.

WENIG: Well, the carriages represent a time pretty much turn of the century, 1900, 1910, when the idea of the automobile ignited the world's fascination with this idea. So, it's an homage to that period of time, to that type of car. And the idea would be the hope to ignite the same type of passions that brought us to this day and age to have love affair with the car.

FRANCIS: I'm reading, though, the price tag is between $150,000 and $175,000?

WENIG: Yes.

FRANCIS: I don't think as a taxpayer in the city, I can afford that.

WENIG: Well, these are privately owned and operated. So, we are working really hard to get the price to a really good point. I don't consider this to be a moneymaker for the first cars we are building for the city. But you know.

FRANCIS: So, privately owned and operated you are going to try and get the taxi company to own that and put it out there? Or who is the owner?

WENIG: Well, the owner would be any company that would want to run this - business. The individual carriage operators or a consortium that would come together to buy these units.

FRANCIS: So, as you work though the numbers, how much would they have to charge per ride in order to make their money back?

WENIG: Well, I believe that the manner, in which they charge clients now would be the same way that they charge clients for these rides. These rides would be able to go through the city where the carriages wouldn't be. So, you have to understand, that the opportunity to own one of these vehicles to replace the carriages is something that they have to make a decision for.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

WENIG: And we're just trying our best to make something that is powerful enough so that will entice people to get on these rides, to further the interests of the city, to be nostalgic and to carry on this tradition going forward. It is, you know, there is a lot of people who come through Central Park.

FRANCIS: Right. They want to do this.

WENIG: People want to do this.

FRANCIS: Yeah, and I mean I don't know if they will be as receptive to things that don't have horses. I've shocked by how the celebrities have really come out, on, you know, Liam Neeson so upset that the horses are going away. Alec Baldwin is so upset that the horses are still there. I mean it seems like celebrities have other things to spend their time on, maybe not. Anyway, thank you for coming on.

WENIG: Yeah, it's remarkable how much passion is behind this, but we're doing our best to try to create a solution for everybody.

FRANCIS: Jason, and we appreciate that. Thanks for coming on.

WENIG: Thank you so much.

FRANCIS: Cool innovation. Coming up, Silicon Valley taking some heat. David Einhorn talking tough about tech. We're going to tell you why he thinks you should get out and do it now.

And speaking of heat, a Keystone protest that is absolutely on fire. We've got cowboys and Indians, protesting. Oh my. "Piles of Money" coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Over to the markets, we are seeing red across the board. Right now, Mark Newton is down for New York Stock Exchange.

MARK NEWTON: Great to be back.

FRANCIS: Mark, what's driving the trade right now?

NEWTON: You know, it's interesting, we are seeing a little bit of a stall out after six straight up days. Lot of the NASDAQ names. NASDAQ has been particularly weak, and really even on this little bounce we've seen, the NASDAQ is underperformed substantially. We're still down about four percent from the highs. So, it's a lot of these high momentum names started to turn back down. You are seeing Netflix weakness, some weakness incurred Green Mountain coffee roasters. Also, a couple of the biotechs are pulling back as well.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

NEWTON: One thing to notice, though, is that industrials have moved back to new high territory. The XLI is set to make a new daily high close today above 53.15. So, that's interesting. And we've continued to see a lot of strength in the industrials.

FRANCIS: Yes, I've heard a lot of people say today that they're looking at the tech earnings that are coming out today and this week for direction going forward. They want to hear from Apple and Facebook. It's a very big deal in terms of how they look at the economy. Do you agree with that?

NEWTON: I do. I think it's tough to pinpoint a few names. The group as a whole is starting to stabilize a little bit, which gives me a little bit more confidence. When I look at charts of techs versus the S&P we seem to be holding and stabilizing. So that should be good. Stocks like Apple have been range bound for four months. So I think investors really want to see signs of this stocks getting back up and breaking out for what the future is protect.

FRANCIS: Thank you, Mark. Appreciate your time.

NEWTON: My pleasure, thank you.

FRANCIS: So we love our protests on the show. You know that, this week in Washington, D.C., multiple events are being held to push for the rejection of the Keystone pipeline. We are live with two of those voices at the National Mall in D.C. Joining me is Bold Nebraska Director Jane Kleib, and a member of the Lower Sioux Nation, Dallas Goldtooth. Dallas, first of all, I love your name. What is your message when you are down there?

DALLAS GOLDTOOTH, LOWER SIOUX DAKOTA NATION MEMBER: Our message is to stand in solidarity with as a native people with ranches, cowboys, farmers, land owners, non-native against the Keystone XL pipeline in its development in all forms, and also to address its source in the tar sense. We stand in solidarity. All folks who don't want to see the dirty oil go through their land, through their country and to protect our air, our water, the land, and to protect our treaty rights as indigenous peoples, I think that's really the purpose what's going on.

FRANCIS: Jane, when you have folks are marching through as cowboys and Indians and pitching teepees, do people take the cause seriously or does it get you the attention that you wanted?

JANE KLEIB, BOLD NEBRASKA DIRECTOR: Yyes, no, we're absolutely getting the attention that we wanted, and we have Americans who are visiting our nation's capital coming in asking questions about what we are doing? And we explain to them about how this tar sands pipeline is coming through America and risks property rights. So our farmers and ranchers don't like the fact that a foreign oil corporation is going to use eminent domain to take their land away. It's been a great learning experience for not only the tribes and farmers and ranchers, but for Americans who ask those questions.

FRANCIS: Dallas, let me ask you, what is the reception like from people? Because, you know, according to the latest "Washington Post" poll, 65 percent of Americans approve of and want the pipeline, it's only 22 percent that don't.

GOLDTOOTH: It's a question about information and knowledge, once you start learning about the pipeline and learning what it's going to do to the land. Learning the effects of the individuals and communities that are directly impacted, to me it seems a no-brainer how ridiculous it is. I mean, the eminent domain question is a huge issue, folks on both sides whether Democrat or Republican can join together on the idea of land being taken away for a greater good which is not going to serve them.

Not going to serve America. It's going to serve outside interests. Talk about job creation, a strip mall will create more sustainable jobs than a pipeline, and I'm not advocating a strip mall, I'm saying that it's foolish to believe that it's anything, but dangerous and destructive to our land and our livelihoods.

FRANCIS: Jane, sustainable energy brings more jobs and brings more manufacturing. Cheap energy isn't good for our economy?

KLEIB: Well, this isn't -- well, this is not cheap energy, this is actually dirty energy and it's bad for not only climate change but risks our water supply. This pipeline is crossing over 2,000 family wells in the state of Nebraska. If the tar sand spill happens in the well, that family's well is done. In some areas they have only one choice to get a well.

FRANCIS: They've already changed the route. Is there any way this pipeline could go through that could make you happier. You don't want it at all under any circumstance?

KLEIB: Yes, they altered the route a little bit it. But still crosses the sand hill, the State Department confirmed that. That's yet another reason in how Trans Canada --

FRANCIS: Is there any route that would make you happy?

KLEIB: We wanted it around the sand hills and aquifer, many folks did. Now that we know about tar sands and the destruction it's doing to other communities in Michigan and Arkansas where spills have happened, we don't want tar sands at all.

FRANCIS: So there is no route that would be OK with you. I'm trying to clarify your position.

KLEIB: No, ma'am.

FRANCIS: All right, Jane, Dallas, thanks to both of you. James, what's your reaction?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: They spent six years to find an environmental case against this. They couldn't find it. Oil is going to get burned whether it's going through Keystone or somewhere else.

FRANCIS: What about the well water she is talking about?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Again, this is an exhaustive review. If there is an environmental case to be made, the Obama administration has plenty of green staffers who would be eager to make the case.

FRANCIS: They put it off a after the midterms and while the majority of Americans want it, it feels like it's never going to happen at this point?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is the fear. The industry is working to get around it, building a lot of rail terminals, finding other ways to move the oil, but the tragedy is for the middle class workers talking about. Terry O'Sullivan --

FRANCIS: What about her argument though that none of the oil is coming here? We're not going to see the benefit of it no matter what?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, it is coming here. That's what rail lines are doing, moving the oil south, and not just from Canada but from the back in shale, North Dakota, it is going down to refiners on the gulf coast. So this is a completely symbolic issue that oil is going to be burned, it's only a question of where, and do we get the benefit as Americans?

FRANCIS: Coming up, Wall Street starting to feel a little unsettled as tech moves onto its turf. How finance could be replaced as New York's main growth engine. Don't move. At the end of the day, it's all about MONEY.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: I'm Melissa Francis with your Fox Business Brief. New home sales unexpectedly plunged last month by 14.5 percent to their lowest levels since July of 2013. It was also the steepest monthly decline since that time as well. Some economists say weather and rising mortgage rates may have played a role.

Toyota retaining its top position in global vehicle sales in the first quarter outselling both GM and Volkswagen. The Japanese automaker set itself a new record with nearly 2.6 million cars. GM came in second with 2.4 million.

And consumer goods maker Procter & Gamble reporting a 5 percent increase in profit. That is due to a surge in sales for its home care products with consumers buying more Tide laundry detergent, in my house, and Duracell batteries also up. That is from the Fox Business Network, giving you the power to prosper.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Silicon Valley is starting to take over Wall Street's turf and experiencing some of the backlash that comes along with the territory. Techs threatening to replace the banking industry as the growth engine of New York, but will increased criticism prove a stumbling block for these internet giants. Here to discuss, Jo Ling Kent, James Freeman is back. We also have Jonathan Hoenig of Capitalistpig.com. He is a Fox News contributor.

Jonathan since you're not here. I'll give you first crack. Bringing the jobs, taking over the real estate, but now they are starting to get the backlash talking about the 1 percent, we're talking about salaries, it's starting for tech. What do you think?

JONATHAN HOENIG, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, you know technology, Melissa, isn't taking over finance. Technology really is finance. Gone are the days when you have the individual specialists organizations or floor traders at major exchanges, technology is driving finance. It's not surprising to see more and more tech companies relocating, jobs office space to Manhattan, the financial capital of the world. Those who decry it are shooting themselves in the foot. That's what you want companies to create jobs fit well for New Yorkers and for the whole country.

FRANCIS: That is so classic. So Google is coming to New York. They are looking to gobble up 600,000 square feet of Manhattan, 80 percent expansion for the company instead of people focusing on the 3,000 employees that are going to be hired, immediately there is talk how they're going to drive up Brent New York. The exact same way they've driven up rent in California. What do you think of the backlash?

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": They are crazy. This is good. The people can now get jobs at Google. Finance is going down, if you look at the housing bubble, the financial bubble, the U.S. probably did have too many people and too much money in the financial industry. This is probably a natural move back.

FRANCIS: At the same time, Jo, fair is fair, if you look at the salaries that have been given away in tech land. They don't get the same criticism until now. Jeff Ubben made the comparison between Silicon Valley and Wall Street yesterday saying Jamie Dimon gets hauled over the coals in New York. For his 20 million bucks, but Eric Schmidt presides over four board meetings and gets paid $100 million," you don't hear boo.

JO LING KENT, FOX BUSINESS: That's true. There isn't necessarily --

FRANCIS: That is an outrage.

KENT: We haven't seen a tech CEO really have a bad fall or have a major crisis in the same way that Wall Street has been perceived. And I think that is still possible to happen. Their reputation still very much on the line. So I think if you look especially, I just finished reading a book called young money and it's all about young bankers.

FRANCIS: Good book?

KENT: It is good. You should read it. It's about reputation and tech has an opportunity, if this is a bubble, to acquire --

FREEMAN: Difference in tech land, they're not paying with our money as taxpayers. They are backed by us and they are backed by us --

FRANCIS: Jonathan, they create cool products that we like and with banks we don't appreciate the fact if it weren't for them, we wouldn't have credit cards?

HOENIG: Exactly right, Melissa, total misunderstanding what financiers create for the economy. We respect technology stars because we can hold an iPhone, use a computer and say I understand this company made this product. But to your point people are ignorant as to the value that hedge funds, investment banks, bracket banks, the whole financial class brings. They don't only create the credit cards, they create the jobs and the capitalists that move the economy forward.

KENT: It's very difficult to define what the value is of Facebook or your iPhone. It's very easy to inflate that, thus the huge numbers.

FRANCIS: We got to move on. Tech giants battling detractors on all fronts the past few days, Green Light Capital CEO David Einhorn sounding alarm on dangerous bubble and shorting high-flying tech stocks. He writes there is a clear consensus that we are witnessing our second tech bubble in 15 years. What is uncertainty is how much further the bubble can expand and what might pop. The Nasdaq is down 5.1 percent since March 5th when it hit highest point 14 years ago. Guys, what do you think? This letter is news that broke on the show yesterday. You had a chance to drill down more on it. What is he saying?

KENT: He basically says the valuations of these companies is no longer traditional. They are no longer looking at actual numbers and based on a lot of --

FRANCIS: So it sounds like a lost bubble.

KENT: But if you look at high-flying stocks. They've come down. The best performers in 2013, we are talking about Trip Advisor, Netflix, Tesla, all of these great stocks and look at them now, they've come down. Somewhere in a bear market already. Some analysts I'm talking to who don't agree with Einhorn are seeing a pullback. This is not necessarily a bubble.

FRANCIS: James, what do you think?

FREEMAN: I'm not sure we should be picking on tech. If you want to survey the landscape for bubbles, given what the Federal Reserve has done, pumping money into the economy, a lot of asset classes. Junk bonds.

FRANCIS: Jonathan, what do you think?

HOENIG: I don't see. I don't see bubble, Melissa. In 2000, the p/e on the S&P 500 was 40. It's nowhere near that today. Certain stocks are expensive, but the market itself is not in a bubble. Transports are at an all-time high.

FRANCIS: OK, thanks to all of you. Good discussion. Heading into the last hour of trading, we have our very own Liz Claman joining us. Liz, what do you have coming up on your big show today?

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS: Well, I can't believe that panel of guests. You guys have the best people. All of you guys are my buddies. So great to see everybody. We have a lot coming up, but remember there is a major widely held company that came out with numbers today, and the numbers were so good they have probably irked an activist investor trying to make Dow chemical break up.

Andrew Liveris is the CEO and chairman and president, the stock moving higher on news that it beat on the bottom line. And we've got the CEO and chairman to talk about why he just feels that this company is being run in the exact correct way. They are shedding assets, which is something that Daniel Lobe of third point, the activist investor has agitated them to do, but he's got a very big man on his side, Warren Buffett. We have him live. Plus we are watching the market. Very tentative at the moment. See you then.

FRANCIS: Wow, huge guest list, look forward to that. Great job.

All right, coming up, millions of Americans know all about the horrors of foreclosure. Our next guest refused to let it get the better of her. You have to listen about how she fought it every inch of the way and got herself a movie deal in the process. All to keep her home. You can never have too much money or too much gumption.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Investors banking on the stock shares of Bank of New York Mellon shooting up at this hour. Nicole Petallides is standing by at the New York Stock Exchange. What are the reports that are driving this higher?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS: Well, you are seeing right now that's a two-day chart. You see instant pop here over the last hour or so. Bank of New York Mellon now up 2.7 percent. There are reports that they are considering a sale of the corporate trust unit. Now if they were to do this possible sale, people speculate that this could account for about $2.5 billion.

One person has been reporting that Goldman Sachs may be helping them with this, Fox Business spoke with Bank of New York Mellon. The spokesman told Fox Business that they are declining to comment on speculation.

In the meantime, this could be good news for shareholders as money could be returned to the shareholders, but you see the stock getting a big pop on the idea of this report that they could sell off the corporate trust unit.

FRANCIS: Nicole Petallides, thank you so much. It's time for spare change, this story takes the cake. Faced with losing her house, Angela Logan baked her way out of foreclosure using grandmother's apple cake recipe. She has a thriving bakery and a teaming movie about her experience.

Angela Logan joins me now. We wanted to do your story because it is such a celebration of the American spirit. You found yourself in this situation more than 2 million Americans found themselves in. Losing your house. Instead of giving up, you said what could I do to change the situation? How did you get to this?

ANGELA LOGAN, MORTGAGE APPLE CAKES: Well, I decided that I wanted to bake 100 cakes in 10 days to help myself save my home and asked my friends and neighbors buy to save my home. I had to go to the bottom to reach out for something else. There was nowhere else to go, I had to reach for whatever I had and my cake is what I had.

FRANCIS: So did you know you were able to sell all them? You are looking at a situation where you can't make your mortgage payment so you have to invest in ingredients. It was a risk?

LOGAN: I need three months of mortgage payments, $2500 each and I knew I had ten days to get it. I put a circle in the middle much the piece of paper and said how many people do I have to buy the cakes? I reached out to friends that worked for organizations I volunteer and asked those people first to help me save my home by buying a cake.

FRANCIS: What was the difference between going to someone and asking them to buy your cake versus saying can you lend me money or give me money?

LOGAN: That's select charity, I guess, I think that a lot of people were having a difficult time.

FRANCIS: Right.

LOGAN: I did not feel like I wanted to ask somebody for something. I wanted to work for it in a way, and I had no job. So buying a cake which was of extraordinary quality, cream cheese frosting.

FRANCIS: Because 40 is a lot for a cake. The media picked up on the story. At one point you had too much demand, you couldn't bake fast enough. What's the end to the story? Do you have the house?

LOGAN: I do. It was a miracle the company shipped the cakes for me. Now we have the same situation, the movie comes out, a lot of demand. We're all set for national shipping.

FRANCIS: That's great. Your web site, how can people buy a cake if they want to?

LOGAN: At www.maccakes.com and see the movie tonight on Up TV at uptv.com.

FRANCIS: OK, terrific. Good for you, Angela. Thanks so much and congratulations. Bosses beware, ever get the feeling some of your team are talking behind you? Turns out millions of workers wouldn't trust employers if their lives depended on it. It is costing businesses in a lot of ways. You can never have too much money. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: A new study from the American Psychological Association says only half of workers think their employers are honest with them. Not only does this make for lousy morale and hurting productivity. James Freeman and Jo Ling Kent are back with me as well. Twenty four percent don't trust their company, 32 percent say their employer is not honest with them. What do you think is the age we live in, our employers are spying on us, get used to it.

KENT: Well, if you're going to have technology in the office. If you're going to operate on a work computer, it should be assumed in good faith pretty much your information is publicly for the company. That comes with the territory.

FRANCIS: They also -- 62 percent say they are treated fairly. So by definition almost 40 percent do not think they are treated fairly. Less than half are happy with their professional growth. Just an unhappiness at work is what I am hearing.

FREEMAN: I don't see it that way. I mean, it's a job after and the fact that over 60 percent, I guess I'm looking at the glass as 60 percent full. I have to tell you, expectations were set very low because I worked living off your tax dollars for the federal government for several years so this has kind of been a dream of transparency, openness and honesty.

FRANCIS: I think there is 100 percent happiness within this building. It speaks to a little bit how the stock market has gone up, corporate profits have increased, wages have lagged, people feel like in general maybe they are not getting their piece of the pie, real quick.

FREEMAN: I don't think the numbers are that bad. It is a workplace, some people will be dissatisfied. Most of them aren't.

KENT: Over the things or small things. Maybe the water cooler or their benefits or e-mails accessed.

FRANCIS: I think they want more money. We always want more money. Maybe they are just unhappy people. Thanks to both of you. That is all we have for now. I hope you are making money and you're happy at work today. "COUNTDOWN" with Liz Claman starts right now.

END

Extracts.SummaryText: ... FRANCIS: Coming up, the very local issue that has international celebs crying out loud. Horses have long been a mainstay in New York Central Park. We're going to show you this very green innovation that could be coming to your town too. Plus, big tech names are taking over New York . Some on Wall Street are starting, to get very nervous. Do you ever have too much money? (COMMERCIAL BREAK) FRANCIS: Wireless carrier AT&T narrowly beating first-quarter earnings, really dropping today. ...

urn:contentItem:5J14-XJ91-JBHT-D03D-00000-00Bill Ackman's Latest Move and Discussion of Insider Trading;[1]2014-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:54ZLexisNexisBill Ackman's Latest Move and Discussion of Insider Trading[1]LanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: We have a lot lined up. In fact the secret is out. Bill Ackman refusing to back down from his billion dollar bet against Herbalife. He's even paying insiders millions to dish some dirt. Two tech giants in two big reports. The burning questions Facebook and Apple finally need to answer as they announce their latest results. And some new voices in the fight against Keystone. We're live from the capital as so-called cowboy and Indian activists march on D.C. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money.

On the heels of the bid to buy Allergan, activist investor Bill Ackman is heeding the headlines again. A new report. So the hedge fund titan is agreeing to spend up to $3.6 million to an Herbalife whistleblower. Here to discuss all that, Charlie Gasparino, James Freeman of "Wall Street Journal" and Ken Mahoney of Mahoney Asset Management. We couldn't stop talking about it even before the show started. He is skating very close to the line here on a number of different bets. Let's talk about Herbalife first. I mean what do you think about paying this whistle-blower?

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: You know, he has a rationale for it, which I saw in the ABC News piece, Brian Ross and another gentleman from ABC News wrote the story. It is online. The rationale that it's, you know, perfectly OK to pay for whistleblower's legal costs and whatever.

FRANCIS: I mean it was - they are going to pay him $250,000 a year for lost work due to whistleblowing, even though he is working, I guess, in a laundromat. So far he's made $80,000. He denied that in the past. But he said, technically he hadn't received the funds yet, so he wasn't lying.

GASPARINO: I want to say this. As someone who has covered these sort of stories, whistleblowers and hedge funds and, you know activist investors, I've never seen people pay off people like this before. This - unless I'm missing something.

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: And why do they have to? I mean .

GASPARINO: I agree.

FREEMAN: If this is such an obvious pyramid scheme, why does Ackman have to spend all the money on lawyering and lobbying and PR to convince people? Federal regulators have information on this company for a long time now. Why this constant campaign?

GASPARINO: And it's not like ..

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Really is a pyramid.

GASPARINO: And it's not like.

FREEMAN: That's what I'm saying - it's not, but it's out there.

GASPARINO: But it's not - and it's not like Bernie Madoff, well, as you see. People keep saying this might be like Bernie Madoff when people looked at him. Bernie Madoff was barely in the news when this stuff was going on.

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: There were a few investigations. This guy is in the news every day.

KEN MAHONEY, MAHONEY ASSET MANAGEMENT: And this one investors are looking at all the time. Because, you know, they say it is not a level playing field. They say that is rigged. You know, these types of stories, you know, shine a spotlight. Wait a second, average investor is not doing these types of things. And look, they call it a gray area, but I think it kind of pushes .

GASPARINO: What you're talking about is how he invested in Allergan, which we were first to report yesterday.

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: You look at CNBC today. That is all they're talking about.

FRANCIS: Not familiar with that channel.

GASPARINO: Right. Not either.

(LAUGHTER)

GASPARINO: But I know - I can't help it. It is in the newsroom. And - but what is interesting is the notion that Bill Ackman can go, be told by a partner..

FRANCIS: You are talking about Allergan?

GASPARINO: Yeah, the Allergan. By Valiant that he was going to make a bid for Allergan. Join me in this bid. Go in undercover, buy options, so it's not seen by anybody. The market doesn't notice. And low and behold, guess what happens? They put the bid in, the market goes up and you make a lot of money. Now, does this violate insider trading laws? No. But if you want to know what gets people mad, more than high frequency trading, this looks pretty - this is a perfect example of why the playing field is unlevel ..

(CROSSTALK)

GASPARINO: By the way - completely illegal.

MAHONEY: How he got the information? You know, it was (INAUDIBLE) flying over his head and drop the note on him and told him this is going on?

FRANCIS: Right.

MAHONEY: You know, individual investors don't get their uncle and tell them this is going on. So .

FRANCIS: And it's interesting - it's interesting that Ackman wears the cap of I'm the activist investor. So, out there for the little guy. You know, I represent the voice of a little guy.

(CROSSTALK)

MAHONEY: There are current investors in those funds.

FRANCIS: That's what activist investors have been saying. But that is not really what it is about. He is the super investor who has the inside track on all the information. And he is part of the problem that we've seen such an unleveled playing field. Some would say, do you agree with that? Do you guys agree with that?

FREEMAN: Two very different situations. On the Herbalife thing I think Ackman's paying a lot of money to gin up federal investigations - and it smells pretty bad. With this situation, when, you know, Valiant and Allergan, I see nothing wrong here. I mean I think it - federal judges, if you look at - as they're deliberating now in Manhattan about what is the limit of insider trading .

GASPARINO: I would say this.

FREEMAN: Their questions are suggesting this is not insider trading.

GASPARINO: I would say - I would say this. I'm against the insider trading laws. I think we should throw them just - right off the bat.

FREEMAN: All right.

GASPARINO: That said, if you are going to have them, this is just how rich people can keep getting rich. There is no way the average guy in the street is ever going to get a tip from Valiant, oh, go buy some stock and join me and buying three options and you let's - and you can make a lot of money.

FRANCIS: It is not going to happen.

MAHONEY: Look, it is not illegal, the way we look at it. But it is not morally or ethically the way to do business. And that's kind of what's coming back, and that's why - I was looking out there.

FRANCIS: It's about - yeah, and it's about the rich getting richer, which is why people are shying away from the stock market. And it's a shame because stock prices are up 175 percent from the bottom. And it is an opportunity for the average person to make money, but they are scared .

FREEMAN: Well, the average person - better prices.

FRANCIS: Hang on. More to discuss after this. Don't move. Don't move.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Moving on now to Amazon. The online retail giant has a new licensing agreement with HBO. Prime members can now get subscription access to content like "The Sopranos" and "Girls." Shareholders, however, not loving this so far. You don't like - Let's go to James Romelli down at the CME. James, what do you think about this? How is it trading?

JAMES ROMELLI: Right. You know, this is a groundbreaking deal in terms of HBO is not going to be offered on Amazon's prime subscription service. And this is first time it is being offered on any streaming subscription based service. However, it's not a very big deal for Amazon. And if we look at the stock price today, it is down around $5. So, it is clear that investors really are not excited over this deal. I think if we take a look at this it's really more of a negative for companies like Netflix than it is a positive for a company like Amazon.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

ROMELLI: It does show that they are going to be willing to go out there and acquire premium content. They have much deeper pockets than Netflix. They're a much larger company. And Netflix does not want them in this space. It shows they're serious about growing that part of their business and they are going to be aggressive about it.

FRANCIS: James, real quick, before you go - what's the feel in the market today? I'm looking at a Dow, that's down 14 points.

FREEMAN: Right. So, we are looking at a market that's down run 14 points. Most of the moves are higher this week. We're on very thin volume. We're still trading pretty thinly holiday week. I say earnings have been pretty good. I think the markets going ahead higher into the end of the week. And I think next week, once the traders are back from holiday we really see a sustained move higher on volume.

FRANCIS: All right, James, thanks so much. Soon, a new report shows that America no longer has the world's wealthiest middle class. That honor now goes to Canada. We can thank the small growth in the U.S. middle incomes compared to other nations. Andrew Liveris is the CEO and chairman and president, the stock moving higher on news that it beat on the bottom line. They are shedding assets, which is something that Daniel Lobe of third point, the activist investor has agitated them to do, but he's got a very big man on his side, Warren Buffett. We have him live. Plus we are watching the market. Very tentative at the moment. See you then.

FRANCIS: Wow, huge guest list, look forward to that. Great job.

All right, coming up, millions of Americans know all about the horrors of foreclosure. Our next guest refused to let it get the better of her. You have to listen about how she fought it every inch of the way and got herself a movie deal in the process. All to keep her home. You can never have too much money or too much gumption.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Investors banking on the stock shares of Bank of New York Mellon shooting up at this hour. Nicole Petallides is standing by at the New York Stock Exchange. What are the reports that are driving this higher?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS: Well, you are seeing right now that's a two-day chart. You see instant pop here over the last hour or so. Bank of New York Mellon now up 2.7 percent. There are reports that they are considering a sale of the corporate trust unit. Now if they were to do this possible sale, people speculate that this could account for about $2.5 billion.

One person has been reporting that Goldman Sachs may be helping them with this, Fox Business spoke with Bank of New York Mellon. The spokesman told Fox Business that they are declining to comment on speculation.

In the meantime, this could be good news for shareholders as money could be returned to the shareholders, but you see the stock getting a big pop on the idea of this report that they could sell off the corporate trust unit.

FRANCIS: Nicole Petallides, thank you so much. It's time for spare change, this story takes the cake. Faced with losing her house, Angela Logan baked her way out of foreclosure using grandmother's apple cake recipe. She has a thriving bakery and a teaming movie about her experience.

Angela Logan joins me now. We wanted to do your story because it is such a celebration of the American spirit. You found yourself in this situation more than 2 million Americans found themselves in. Losing your house. Instead of giving up, you said what could I do to change the situation? How did you get to this?

ANGELA LOGAN, MORTGAGE APPLE CAKES: Well, I decided that I wanted to bake 100 cakes in 10 days to help myself save my home and asked my friends and neighbors buy to save my home. I had to go to the bottom to reach out for something else. There was nowhere else to go, I had to reach for whatever I had and my cake is what I had.

FRANCIS: So did you know you were able to sell all them? You are looking at a situation where you can't make your mortgage payment so you have to invest in ingredients. It was a risk?

LOGAN: I need three months of mortgage payments, $2500 each and I knew I had ten days to get it. I put a circle in the middle much the piece of paper and said how many people do I have to buy the cakes? I reached out to friends that worked for organizations I volunteer and asked those people first to help me save my home by buying a cake.

FRANCIS: What was the difference between going to someone and asking them to buy your cake versus saying can you lend me money or give me money?

LOGAN: That's select charity, I guess, I think that a lot of people were having a difficult time.

FRANCIS: Right.

LOGAN: I did not feel like I wanted to ask somebody for something. I wanted to work for it in a way, and I had no job. So buying a cake which was of extraordinary quality, cream cheese frosting.

FRANCIS: Because 40 is a lot for a cake. The media picked up on the story. At one point you had too much demand, you couldn't bake fast enough. What's the end to the story? Do you have the house?

LOGAN: I do. It was a miracle the company shipped the cakes for me. Now we have the same situation, the movie comes out, a lot of demand. We're all set for national shipping.

FRANCIS: That's great. Your web site, how can people buy a cake if they want to?

LOGAN: At www.maccakes.com and see the movie tonight on Up TV at uptv.com.

FRANCIS: OK, terrific. Good for you, Angela. Thanks so much and congratulations. Bosses beware, ever get the feeling some of your team are talking behind you? Turns out millions of workers wouldn't trust employers if their lives depended on it. It is costing businesses in a lot of ways. You can never have too much money. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: A new study from the American Psychological Association says only half of workers think their employers are honest with them. Not only does this make for lousy morale and hurting productivity. James Freeman and Jo Ling Kent are back with me as well. Twenty four percent don't trust their company, 32 percent say their employer is not honest with them. What do you think is the age we live in, our employers are spying on us, get used to it.

KENT: Well, if you're going to have technology in the office. If you're going to operate on a work computer, it should be assumed in good faith pretty much your information is publicly for the company. That comes with the territory.

FRANCIS: They also -- 62 percent say they are treated fairly. So by definition almost 40 percent do not think they are treated fairly. Less than half are happy with their professional growth. Just an unhappiness at work is what I am hearing.

FREEMAN: I don't see it that way. I mean, it's a job after and the fact that over 60 percent, I guess I'm looking at the glass as 60 percent full. I have to tell you, expectations were set very low because I worked living off your tax dollars for the federal government for several years so this has kind of been a dream of transparency, openness and honesty.

FRANCIS: I think there is 100 percent happiness within this building. It speaks to a little bit how the stock market has gone up, corporate profits have increased, wages have lagged, people feel like in general maybe they are not getting their piece of the pie, real quick.

FREEMAN: I don't think the numbers are that bad. It is a workplace, some people will be dissatisfied. Most of them aren't.

KENT: Over the things or small things. Maybe the water cooler or their benefits or e-mails accessed.

FRANCIS: I think they want more money. We always want more money. Maybe they are just unhappy people. Thanks to both of you. That is all we have for now. I hope you are making money and you're happy at work today. "COUNTDOWN" with Liz Claman starts right now.

END

urn:contentItem:60RW-YK91-F07F-830W-00000-00Bill Barr Is About to Blow Up the Antitrust Case Against Google: Report2020-09-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisNEWSBill Barr Is About to Blow Up the Antitrust Case Against Google: ReportBryan Menegus

Several interested parties in the U.S. government have been looking to put Google’s head on a spike, and while undoubtedly there’s been some degree of jockeying between them for which will ultimately get the credit, they’ve been proceeding with care and ca... Several interested parties in the U.S. government have been looking to put Google’s head on...

Several interested parties in the U.S. government have been looking to put Google’s head on a spike, and while undoubtedly there’s been some degree of jockeying between them for which will ultimately get the credit, they’ve been proceeding with care and ca...

Several interested parties in the U.S. government have been looking to put Google’s head on a spike, and while undoubtedly there’s been some degree of jockeying between them for which will ultimately get the credit, they’ve been proceeding with care and caution in the interest of building an ironclad case against a particularly canny opponent. Leave it to Bill Barr — who in a better world would instead star in a live-action remake of Droopy Dog — to take all that hard work and piss it away. Per reporting in the New York Times , “Justice Department officials told lawyers involved in the antitrust inquiry into Alphabet […] to wrap up their work by the end of September.” These lawyers apparently viewed the new, abrupt deadline — against an enormously powerful company with nearly unlimited resources to throw at a comprehensive legal defence — as “arbitrary.” In all likeliness it’s anything but arbitrary. As we near the general election in November, the Trump camp is looking for a win to hang its hat on. We’ve already seen the president decide — seemingly mid-interview with Axios’s Jonathan Swan — to cut the number of troops deployed in Afghanistan by half , and likewise claim during his keynote speech at the RNC that he will release a covid-19 vaccine. Not coincidentally, both of these miraculous claims are projected (by Trump and seemingly only Trump) to come to fruition around November. Breaking up Google, which is increasingly a source of ire for Republicans and Democrats (albeit for wildly different reasons) appears to be a gambit by Barr to find that win — or at least the appearance of one. We’ve reached out to Google and the Department of Justice for comment and will update if we hear back. As mentioned, the DOJ isn’t the only game in town where fining, regulating, or otherwise frustrating Google’s market dominance is concerned. A coalition of 50 state attorneys general is also probing the company, while the FTC, the House’s Antitrust Subcommittee , and the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee have ongoing investigations more broadly into the practices of big tech. All have been gathering evidence for a year or more, which is what makes Barr’s hastiness particularly egregious. Per the Times: Some lawyers in the department worry that Mr. Barr’s determination to bring a complaint this month could weaken their case and ultimately strengthen Google’s hand, according to interviews with 15 lawyers who worked on the case or were briefed on the department’s strategy […] Many career staff members in the antitrust division, including more than a dozen who were hired during the Trump administration, considered the evidence solid that Google’s search and advertising businesses violated antitrust law. But some told associates that Mr. Barr was forcing them to come up with “half-baked” cases so he could unveil a complaint by Sept. 30. As is the case with most would-be totalitarians , the appearance of strength for Trump is often pursued at the expense of actually wielding power effectively. If true, Barr’s reported plan to jump the gun on a Google antitrust case is a prime example. By looking the part and going after Google now, he would be likely to undermine the other existing cases against the company. If, say, Google manages to dodge claims by the DOJ of a monopoly on web search advertising (of which it controls more than 90% of the market), that becomes precedent the FTC or House needs to overcome to prove said monopoly exists. Regulating big tech — and regulating it in a smart and comprehensive way — would be a steep uphill climb in the best of political climates. Leave it to Trump and his lackeys to carve that hill into a sheer cliff face and slather it in grease. Maybe someone else will clean it up.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60S4-FF21-JCMN-Y06V-00000-00Bill Barr's 'Antitrust Crackdown' Of Google Is Going To Be A Weaponized Farce2020-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill Barr's 'Antitrust Crackdown' Of Google Is Going To Be A Weaponized FarceKarl Bode

Sep 04, 2020( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) Back in May we discussed how strange it was[1] that folks would assume that Bill Barr's "antitrust inquiry" into Google would be in good faith, given Barr's history of, well, everything. It's abundantly clear by now that Barr's DOJ has been eager to weaponize antitrust to go after companies Trumpland is politically opposed to (like the legal cannabis sector[2]), while turning a blind eye[3] to every monopolistic whim of his BFFs in the telecom sector. The DOJ's petty lawsuit against California automakers[4] also made it clear there's no real intellectual consistency being applied at the Trump DOJ when it comes to antitrust. Now reports indicate that Barr has been expediting the DOJ "antitrust inquiry" into Google[5], in a transparent bid to get his "crackdown of big tech" into the headlines during the election cycle:"In an unusual move, Mr. Barr placed the investigation under Jeffrey A. Rosen, the deputy attorney general, whose office would not typically oversee an antitrust case.

Mr. Barr and Mr. Delrahim also disagreed on how to approach the investigation, and Mr. Barr had told aides that the antitrust division had been asleep at the switch for decades, particularly in scrutinizing the technology industry."Context here matters. As the net neutrality fracas made abundantly clear, Google has long been the nemesis of the telecom sector, which has been clamoring for greater scrutiny of "big tech"[6] while successfully convincing the Trump administration to neuter pretty much all oversight of telecom monopolies[7]. Barr, a former Verizon lawyer, has eagerly rubber stamped numerous telecom consolidation efforts with less than zero interest in hard data, most notably the job and competition eroding merger between T-Mobile and Sprint. Despite an ocean of data showing that deal would reduce competition, harm sector pay, kill overall jobs, and result in higher prices, T-Mobile did everything in its power to kiss the Trump administration's ass[8] to gain merger approval. As a result, DOJ antitrust boss Makan Delrahim not only approved the deal without listening to experts, but used his personal phone and email accounts[9] to help lobby the deal to approval. That is what "antitrust enforcement" looks like at Donald Trump and Bill Barr's DOJ. It's just cronyism dressed up as serious adult policy. Now, apparently, we're to believe that Barr genuinely cares about "big tech" monopolies. The speed at which Barr is moving to shovel the inquiry into the spotlight for election season fodder has apparently upset many staffers at the DOJ, who say the rush has eroded the integrity of the investigation:"Many career staff members in the antitrust division, including more than a dozen who were hired during the Trump administration, considered the evidence solid that Google's search and advertising businesses violated antitrust law. But some told associates that Mr. Barr was forcing them to come up with 'half-baked' cases so he could unveil a complaint by Sept. 30, according to three people with knowledge of the discussions. Some lawyers who felt they needed more time laid out their concerns in the memo and left the case; about 20 lawyers remain on the team."Confirming what we all knew: The imminent antitrust case against Google from the Barr DOJ will be a political hit job. 'Some [career staff at DOJ] told associates that Mr. Barr was forcing them to come up with 'half-baked' cases so he could unveil a complaint by Sept. 30' pic.twitter.com/135phfuSFj[10] — Alec (@AlecStapp) September 3, 2020[11]There are clearly several goals here for Billy Barr. The first is to get the false[12] "Conservatives are being unfairly targeted" victimization complex in headlines ahead of the election. The second is to gain leverage over companies like Google as they ponder cracking down on Trump disinformation during an election season. The third is to aid telecom giants and folks like Rupert Murdoch[13] that have long coveted Silicon Valley's advertising revenue. None of these motivations have anything to do with a genuine "antitrust inquiry," but we're going to spend the next month or two watching experts and journalists, who should know better, pretend otherwise. Some economists have pointed out that Barr's quest to use antitrust to police viewpoint diversity not only isn't particularly legally sound, it (like so much in Trumpland) flies in the face of everything Conservatives claimed they believed in over the last thirty years. For example, there was decades of right wing histrionics about the "fairness doctrine" -- a concern that's suddenly and mysteriously absent as Barr attempts to mutilate antitrust to support his quest to police "viewpoint diversity": The irony here is that conservatives (under Reagan) revoked the FCC's fairness doctrine, arguing it wasn't a legitimate public policy objective, but Barr wants to use the antitrust laws to enforce viewpoint diversity. Is it happy hour yet? pic.twitter .com/zEdBcKQe62[14]; — Hal Singer (@HalSinger) September 3, 2020[15]Google engages in plenty of dodgy behavior that requires intelligent, adult antitrust and regulatory scrutiny. But Iran Contra cover upper[16] Billy Barr, fresh off endless bouts of sycophancy, obvious falsehoods, and antitrust abuse, is probably the last guy capable of doing so with even a modicum of integrity. [ 1]: https://www.techdirt .com/articles/20200520/09524444537/so-wait-people-really-think-barr-dojs-investigation-into-google-is-good-faith.shtml [ 2]: https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/23/politics/elias-testimony-barr-cannabis-trump-automobile-california/index.html [ 3]: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/19/technology/sprint-t-mobile-merger-antitrust-official.html [ 4]: https://www.theverge.com/2020/2/7/21128684/doj-antitrust-investigation-closed-trump-ford-vw [ 5]: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/03/us/politics/google-antitrust-justice-department.html?smtyp=cur&smid=tw-nytimes [ 6]: https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190611/13180142374/heres-why-net-neutrality-still-matters-one-year-after-repeal.shtml [ 7]: https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190611/13180142374/heres-why-net-neutrality-still-matters-one-year-after-repeal.shtml [ 8]: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/t-mobile-acknowledges-its-patronage-of-trumps-washington-hotel-increased-sharply-after-announcement-of-merger-with-sprint/2019/03/05/d123be66-3ecb-11e9-922c-64d6b7840b82_story.html [ 9]: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/19/technology/sprint-t-mobile-merger-antitrust-official.html [ 10]: https://t.co/135phfuSFj [ 11]: https://twitter.com/AlecStapp/status/1301612734891646976?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 12]: https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190731/17202442692/enough-with-myth-that-big-tech-is-censoring-conservatives-that-law-requires-them-to-be-neutral.shtml [ 13]: https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190929/16484543093/telcos-rupert-murdoch-pushing-nonsense-story-that-google-helping-keep-your-internet-activity-more-private-is-antitrust-violation.shtml [ 14]: https://t.co/zEdBcKQe62 [ 15]: https://twitter.com/HalSinger/status/1301632301248503811?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 16]: https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/pajdb9/william-barrs-been-accused-of-a-presidential-cover-up-before
