Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T4K-H0S1-JB20-G1B5-00000-00Bill Clinton's Labor Secretary, Robert Reich, wrote that the entire Trump presidency ought to be annulled; Death of Senator John McCain touched off a political furor in Washington; Justice Department official Bruce Ohr set to testify behind closed doors to Congress; liberals have turned to corporations to censor people they disagree with; The Chinese government plans to rank all 1.4 billion of its citizens according to their political reliability; Northeastern University professor Suzanna Danuta Walters says women have every right to hate men, all men, because men have done women wrong, all women by all men; A Russian company has unveiled a 13-foot 5-ton bulletproof robot2018-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTMark Steyn, Julian Epstein, Byron York, Mark Penn, Gordon Chang, Jason NicholsNEWSDomestic082701cb.260Bill Clinton's Labor Secretary, Robert Reich, wrote that the entire Trump presidency ought to be annulled; Death of Senator John McCain touched off a political furor in Washington; Justice Department official Bruce Ohr set to testify behind closed doors to Congress; liberals have turned to corporations to censor people they disagree with; The Chinese government plans to rank all 1.4 billion of its citizens according to their political reliability; Northeastern University professor Suzanna Danuta Walters says women have every right to hate men, all men, because men have done women wrong, all women by all men; A Russian company has unveiled a 13-foot 5-ton bulletproof robotTucker Carlson, Greg Gutfeld

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening, and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT. One of the benefits of living for a while is you get to see how the story ends. It sometimes is a little depressing.

If you are over 40, you probably remember Robert Reich. He was Bill Clinton's Labor Secretary. He was a liberal among moderators in that administration, but a thoughtful and engaging person. His views weren't mainstream, but he certainly wasn't stupid or a hater.

Well, that was all before Trump. Like a lot of people in our ruling class, Robert Reich is now a completely different person. Just the other day, Reich wrote that the entire Trump presidency ought to be annulled. Not just ended prematurely, that's no longer radical enough, but erased from history, forgotten by decree.

America must reset to the first Monday in November 2016 like none of it ever happened. We have to retroactively Photoshop an awful lot of pictures. But according to Reich, it's the only remedy.

Reality isn't tolerable, it should be banned. Reich was dead serious apparently. Keep in mind that 20 years ago, people considered him impressive. Some still do, which tells you a lot about the state of our intellectual leaders.

People still defend John Brennan too, even after he revealed on television that there's something seriously wrong with him. Officials who run the CIA ought to be sober and reasonable and even-tempered.

It's too powerful a job, with too little oversight, and too little accountability for a wacko. That would be dangerous for the country. And yet, over the weekend, there was Brennan once again charging a political opponent with a death penalty offense on the basis of zero evidence. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've been having a hell of a time here on this show trying to get my guest to say the word treason. I think the President is guilty of that and you used terms like that. You said, after Helsinki, it was nothing short of treasonous, which sounds to me like treasonous.

JOHN BRENNAN, FORMER CIA DIRECTOR: Treasonous is defined as a betrayal of trust, as well as aiding and abetting the enemy, and so that was the word that came to my mind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Things are accelerating fast. Trump is a racist, became Trump as a traitor, which has now become Trump as a non-person who must be erased from our collective memory. The Left is officially out of epithets. All that's left is physical harm. Who will be the first to call for that; it feels inevitable at this point.

Mark Stein is an author and columnist, and he joins us tonight. So what do you make of annulling the Trump presidency? Mark?

MARK STEYN, CONSERVATIVE CANADIAN AUTHOR AND POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: Well, I think this is rather like the famous episode of Dallas, where after they wrote off an entire season as not having gone anywhere, and Pam Ewing stepped into the shower and there was Bobby Ewing who was supposed to be dead restored to life.

And Robert Reich seems to basically be proposing the same solution here, that Robert Reich will step into the shower and there will be President Hillary Clinton magnificently, which I hope that's not a bit too vivid for you, actually, as I was halfway through that image.

(LAUGHTER)

It got a bit too vivid for me.

CARLSON: It's pretty vivid.

STEYN: But that does actually reflect the level of denial here. If you recall, going back to November 2016, we heard all this stuff about, "Oh you know, America is unique in having the peaceful transfer of power," which I don't quite accept.

I mean generally speaking, when they get a new Prime Minister in Denmark, they don't throw the old one off the Parliament building or anything. There are other countries that have peaceful transfers of power.

(LAUGHTER)

What's interesting here is that actually they can't accept that, and the denialism, which back a year-and-a-half ago, was just like with fake Newsweek covers showing the rightful President is now extending to former cabinet secretaries--

CARLSON: That's right.

STEYN: --actually arguing for the erasure of the historical record and sort of resetting things to year zero. And actually that is harmful to the so- called peaceful transfer of power. And in that sense, Reich should be ashamed of himself.

CARLSON: So but that's kind of the key. Here you have a, not just some pundit on CNN or whatever, but here you have the former cabinet secretary and a well-regarded one, I mean I know him and he is a legitimately smart guy, and then a former CIA Director who is not a legitimately smart guy, but still a former CIA director.

I mean these are the pillars of the establishment. What is it macro question about Trump that drives the ruling class to say things like this, irrational things, crazy things?

STEYN: Well, I think there is a general presumption that it's not just that he won, but that he shouldn't have won.

CARLSON: Right.

STEYN: And therefore, because he shouldn't have won, he cannot really have won, and that's why you have to have this - basically, this dance of speculation.

Now, the treason accusation I think is actually - for a start, treason is giving aid and comfort to the enemy and actually Russia isn't the enemy at the moment. In fact, it was President Obama who mocked the very idea that Russia was even a sort of geopolitical rival of any kind.

So, we're not at war with Russia. The idea that that is actually possible of rising to the level of treason is faintly absurd. But I think it's the need to delegitimize. And a couple of cycles ago, that just meant mocking the other guy as being stupid and being unworthy of it, and all the rest of it. But it's actually gone on to something far more dangerous, which is actually delegitimizing the entire system.

When you have these major political figures saying that in effect the peaceful transfer of power is not possible, it can't possibly happen, therefore if it does happen, it's illegitimate, it's not so much this or that President that they are delegitimizing, but actually the very possibility of civilized self-government by free people.

CARLSON: Well, exactly.

So if the supposed adults on the left, Reich and Brennan and many others, are talking themselves into this frenzy, where each round becomes more extreme than last, how long before someone convinces himself that we need to storm the White -- we need to take action, like physical action here?

STEYN: Well, you know--

CARLSON: That's the terminus of this, right? How could it not be?

STEYN: Well, that's what makes this at some level ridiculous. I mean, for Bill Maher, just before that bit with Brennan, said that this was the third biggest crisis in the Republic -- in America's history.

The Revolutionary War and then the Civil War, and now this. Well, what are you doing about it, Bill? Yes, you're having another decaf Macchiato and finding another Canadian singer-songwriter to date. You're not pledging your life, your fortune, and your sacred honor, are you?

By the way, speaking of treason, if he is dating another Canadian singer- songwriter, that's like George Washington dating a United Empire Loyalist at the time of the Revolutionary War. So, he's not even serious about what he's saying, and that's what makes it decadent.

If even this is, as Bill Maher says, the third great crisis in American history or it's just something you guys are talking about over you're Sauvignon blanc for a giggle, but if they're not serious about it, they shouldn't be saying it, because somebody will take it seriously and that's the real danger.

CARLSON: Meanwhile, the middle class dies and nobody cares.

Mark Steyn, thank you very much for that. Great to see you.

STEYN: Thanks a lot, Tucker.

CARLSON: So is it legal, is it even possible to annul a presidency? Julian Epstein is a Democrat and former counsel to the House Judiciary Committee, he joins us now.

So, Julian, I have noticed that the Left has become more than anything a religious movement and the use of the term annulment kind of proves it. If the presidency were annulled, as Reich suggests, would heretics who persist on acknowledging that Trump was once President, would they be punished?

JULIAN EPSTEIN, FORMER CHIEF DEMOCRATIC COUNSEL TO HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: It's a funny way to put the question. I don't think annulment is a serious argument, I don't think we're at the threshold of impeachment yet.

I think there is a tendency going on with Democrats right now, as there was during `98 Clinton impeachment for people in the opposition party to scream loud--

CARLSON: Yes.

EPSTEIN: --and to try to get an attention and to scream kind of louder than the other, because it helps with clicks on websites and it helps get them on television. But I don't think it's a serious argument.

CARLSON: But it's a different-

EPSTEIN: I think--

CARLSON: You and I had many debates during the impeachment--

EPSTEIN: Yes.

CARLSON: So we've known each other, and there were people who were claiming that Bill Clinton murdered someone at Mena airfield--

EPSTEIN: Precisely.

CARLSON: --you know, there was a lot of that stuff.

EPSTEIN: Vince Foster.

CARLSON: For sure.

But it wasn't called from former cabinet secretary level.

EPSTEIN: Dan Burton, Chairman of Congressional Committee.

CARLSON: I know you had a member of Congress who had all kinds of theories, but he was embarrassed to those theories. And when confronted with music, "Oh I didn't really think that." Here you have pillars of the Democratic establishment saying on television things that are so far out in extreme, I'm not even sure how to respond to them.

Does that make you uncomfortable?

EPSTEIN: I don't know if he's a pillar of the Democratic establishment. I think he was a Labor Secretary under Clinton and I think he's a very good economist. I think he's a sharp thinker as an economist.

He is not a lawyer and I don't think he's a legal scholar, and I think he'd probably do better staying away from that. I think there were plenty of Republican members of Congress that said very extremist things during Clinton impeachment.

So, I think it happens on both sides. It's a natural thing that occurs when they are in the middle of this.

CARLSON: I don't think anybody accused Bill Clinton of treason. So, here you have--

EPSTEIN: People accused Bill Clinton of murder.

CARLSON: But not in public. I mean they sort of whispered about it, but you didn't have for example a former head of the CIA. Does it bother you actually that John Brennan, who was complimented by Republicans by the way when he first got in, I'll concede that.

But he was the head of the CIA and now he's accusing a political opponent of a death-penalty offense with no evidence. Does it bother you that he ran the most powerful intelligence agency in the world?

EPSTEIN: Well, I think what Brennan was referring to, and people use treason in different ways, people sometimes use treason in a legal sense and sometimes people use treason in a more vernacular sense, and I think what Brennan was talking about was Trump continually cozying with Putin, who I think most Republicans would agree is an enemy of the United States. He's certainly an opponent of the United States.

CARLSON: Well, I wouldn't agree on that. I don't know, if I would agree with that, I mean certainly - he's certainly no more bloodthirsty than lots of Middle Eastern tyrants.

EPSTEIN: I think if you look at what he's done with the airliners, I think if you were raised in Crimea and Syria, I don't think he's a guy that's looking up for US interests.

CARLSON: No, of course he's not looking out for US interest, and he would undermine US interests, so would a lot of the tyrants.

EPSTEIN: That's the point. So, look, I think you can go back and forth. We could go back, as we did in `98 and you can go back, you can find extremists on both sides who will say things that again I think are designed to get attention, get on television, get clickbait for the things- -

CARLSON: Sure, but then you also -- and what you're saying is absolutely right. But you also have people like, I don't know, the ranking Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee who on this show accused me of carrying water for Putin, because I had sincere questions about the evidence of collusion.

So you do have a kind of different level of extremism, I would argue, but it leads to this question, which is, if Trump is guilty of these crimes that virtually everyone on the Left alleges, then why are we just saying out loud there's an impeachment coming? Why are Democrats ashamed of that?

EPSTEIN: As to the question of extremism, there's a lot of extremism going on, on both sides, and I hope as a thoughtful guy that you are that you would denounce it, the extremism that's occurring on the Right. I denounce the extremism that's occurring on the Left.

I think the Robert Reich article was ridiculous. That's the first point.

The second point is, not everybody in the Left is saying Trump is guilty of crimes. I don't think there's proof yet that Trump is guilty of crimes. I think the question on campaign finance, as we were discussing before we came on air, I don't think that reaches an impeachable offense and I think it's questionable as whether it reaches a legal offense because of the ambiguity of the campaign finance laws.

We can talk about that more--

CARLSON: No, of course I agree.

EPSTEIN: I think the question on collusion rests entirely on whether Trump had advanced knowledge of any illegal activity that was connected to Russian hacking. That has not been proven yet. So, this Democrat is not alleging a crime as it involves Donald Trump.

CARLSON: But you know as well as I the pressure, and the polls bear this out, the pressure from Democratic voters to impeach, if Democrats retake the house, will be so overwhelming that what Speaker could look at the people who just put him or her in that position and say, "You know, we're not impeaching." Can they resist--

EPSTEIN: Well I was going to say, one of the reasons that I think there's so much pressure around these investigations is how badly the Trump White House has handled the Russian investigation matter.

It looks at every turn that they are trying to cover up crimes, whether it is the firing, the threatened firings, the promises of pardons, would be all of the flipping of the witnesses, the accountant has flipped on the President, his attorney has flipped on the President, campaign manager, the poor way and--

(CROSSTALK)

CARLSON: Julian, is looking guilty the same as being guilty?

EPSTEIN: No it's not. No, Tucker, not in a legal world, but in a political way, you know as well as I do, that the actions of this White House have looked guilty from the beginning, have made them look guilty. It doesn't mean that they're guilty in a legal sense, but it has been handled horribly.

CARLSON: OK.

EPSTEIN: Now, the Democrats, where the Democrats ought to be and what I would argue and I've spoken to Democrats on the Hill, is they should not be coming to legal conclusions or conclusions about impeachment of this.

CARLSON: But can they resist impeachment?

EPSTEIN: What they should be--

CARLSON: Can they -- their voters want it.

EPSTEIN: If you are smart - well, this is the problem with the polarized politics as we play to the extreme bases. And Republicans do this, I think I would argue more so than Democrats do, but we can disagree about that.

CARLSON: I don't see that at all.

EPSTEIN: We can disagree about that. But if Democrats were smart, they would tell the base that we're not going to kind of kowtow to the impulses that may make you feel better emotionally. We're going to do what you and I would probably agree ought to be done here.

CARLSON: (LAUGHTER)

EPSTEIN: Listen to the point. Listen to the--

CARLSON: If you can find one Democratic leader - look, I agree with you, of course.

EPSTEIN: It's the democratic leadership.

CARLSON: If you can find one Democratic leader with the huevos to say something like that on television, I'll give you $20.

EPSTEIN: Well, I think that's basically what the Democrats are saying, in other words, and what the Democrats ought to be saying, Tucker, is--

CARLSON: We're almost out of time.

EPSTEIN: --we are not going to make conclusions about impeachment, we're not going to make conclusions for our prosecution, we want facts to come out, we want to protect the Independent Counsel and all the other investigations that are under way. We should protect the integrity of the investigation--

CARLSON: Well, then they should tell the truth

EPSTEIN: --and allow the facts to come out.

CARLSON: Then they should tell the treason folks to shut up.

EPSTEIN: All right. And you ought to be there and I ought to be there, and we had to say, let's make a decision--

CARLSON: I've been saying that since day one totally, it's been two years.

EPSTEIN: Let's make a decision. Are you for the Republican plan, the Senate Bipartisan Republican plan, that protects the special counsel (ph).

CARLSON: --for running the government and like rescuing the middle class from oblivion, that was the whole point of this.

EPSTEIN: Well, what about the Grassley bill that would protect this special account -- special counsel.

CARLSON: Oh I don't know, I don't think we should have any special counsels of any kind, it's unaccountable to the voters. We have mechanisms.

EPSTEIN: But now that there is an investigation, do you think the (INAUDIBLE).

CARLSON: I just want it to go away and think about what-

EPSTEIN: (LAUGHTER)

CARLSON: No, I'm serious, and think about why 70,000 people died of drug ODs last year, there's like real stuff going on.

EPSTEIN: But you just said that you think the integrity of the investigation ought to be protected with all the facts on the table.

CARLSON: All right. I think, it's just the whole thing is so stupid, I've run out of patience for it, but that's not why I asked you to come on tonight.

Julian, thank you very much.

EPSTEIN: Thanks for having me, Tucker.

CARLSON: Multiple investigations into Russia's interference in our election still haven't proved that Moscow colluded with Trump. So, how long can an investigation that has turned up no actual evidence continue; that's ahead.

We also have the latest on the recent news surrounding the death of Senator John McCain and the political furor it touched off in Washington today. Stay tuned.

Senator John McCain, who passed away this weekend at the age of 81, was a man of florid passions. He loved what he loved and he hated what he hated. High atop his dislike list was Donald Trump.

McCain despised Trump. Trump for his part despised McCain right back. And to their credit, neither man ever pretended otherwise. McCain attacked Trump almost until his final day. After McCain died, Trump at first could barely bring himself to mourn. He sent a brief tweet and then raised the white house flags too soon for many critics.

Now, the root of this dispute between Senator McCain and the president is murky; each side has a different story. What's clear though is where the press stands in this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BROOKE BALDWIN, HOST, CNN NEWSROOM: To watch the President with President Kenyatta of Kenya twice, you know, not saying anything about this hero, this lion of a man, I'm so -- it's despicable, it's despicable.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The President who repeatedly refused to say anything about a war hero, despite being asked today again and again and again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: How dare he? Well, there's been a lot of this today, almost exclusively from the Left. On one level, it's amusing because these are the very same people of course who called John McCain a racist ten years ago for daring to run against the Anointed One.

A month before that election in 2008, Congressman John Lewis of Georgia compared John McCain to George Wallace, and then tried to connect him to the 1963 Birmingham church bombings, if you could imagine.

Fast forward to this weekend, Lewis described McCain probably the most hawkish Senator in American history as, "A warrior for peace. He will be deeply missed by people all around the world." In other words, never mind the racist stuff, it was never personal.

For the Left, everything is about political expedience, even obituaries. More troubling though, more interesting too, is the claim you've just heard that it's, "despicable not to mourn Senator McCain in a certain way." Not just impolite, but immoral and forbidden.

When people in authority - people with TV shows for example decide that they can dictate what emotions you're allowed to feel, you should worry. McCain knew that well. He spent five and a half years as a captive in a society just like that, and he spent the rest of his life fighting against it.

He hated authoritarians above all. John McCain was a complicated person, but a great man. If you really want to honor his memory, you ought to let people make up their own minds about what they think.

Well, Justice Department official Bruce Ohr played a central role in the Obama administration's targeting and spying on the Trump campaign, feeding information from Christopher Steele to his contacts at the FBI.

Tomorrow, we're going to learn more because he is set to testify behind closed doors to Congress. Who is Bruce Ohr, the Washington Examiner's Byron York has been covering this story from the very beginning, and as we think one of the most trustworthy sources on it.

So, Byron, I read The New York Times every day because I'm paid to, and I just read a piece saying that Bruce Ohr was an insignificant figure at the Justice Department. No one ever heard of him, don't pay attention to Bruce Ohr. All of a sudden, he emerges as a central figure in this story. What am I to make?

BYRON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: Well, it read almost like a defense brief on the eve of his testimony. But Bruce Ohr was the fourth ranking official in the Obama Justice Department.

And one of the big questions that investigators in Congress have tried to find out about the dossier was how high did knowledge of the dossier go in the Justice Department? Was it a few guys in the FBI, did people above that know--

CARLSON: Yes.

YORK: --and above that. And so, you've gotten to Bruce Ohr. Now, if the number four knew, did the number three, did the number two know, and did the Attorney General know? That's -- those are probably some of the questions that Ohr will be asked, unfortunately behind closed doors tomorrow.

CARLSON: It's a little bit striking that you said that the piece about Bruce Ohr in The New York Times read like a defense brief. The story here is not just about President Trump and whatever crimes he's alleged to have committed. The story is about the Obama administration, and whether or not one administration spied on an opposing political campaign using our intel agencies.

Why wouldn't the press be anxious to know more about that, since it sets a pretty troubling precedent for future administrations?

YORK: Well, it does. And the whole idea is what was the Obama administration doing with Christopher Steele, that former British spy, who was hired by the Clinton campaign and the DNC to search for dirt in Russia on Donald Trump? What was the Justice Department doing about that?

And one of the most fascinating aspects of all this, which Ohr will be asked about, is Steele was dying to get negative information about Trump into the press before the election, so it could affect the election. And he was not supposed to talk to the press, but he did.

CARLSON: By his own admission, by the way, this is not something you're assuming.

YORK: Correct, and this is known for as a fact. He did it in September and in October of 2016, right before the election. So, the FBI -- this is really, really against the rules for FBI sources. So, they terminated him as a source, but they wanted to keep using him.

So, what they did in the months after the election, all the way up to at least May of 2017, was have Bruce Ohr to Christopher Steele, and then come back to the FBI and tell the FBI what Steele told him.

And the FBI, by the way, made what are called 302 reports--

CARLSON: Yes.

YORK: --which is a write-up notes of interviews. They made them for each one of these things. And we don't know what they are, because the Justice Department will not let Congress have them; they've let some members of Congress read them.

And all of these are questions that the Congress is going to want to know like, what did Christopher steel tell you.

CARLSON: And I think the rest of us have a right to know.

YORK: Absolutely.

CARLSON: We have a right to trust our government.

Byron York, great to see you, thank you for that.

YORK: Thank you.

CARLSON: Well, liberals have turned to corporations to censor people they disagree with. That's accelerating quickly. Where will it end? We're going to speak with a knowledgeable source on that next.

CARLSON: Well, the Bill of Rights is a stumbling block on the way to shutting down speech that the Left doesn't like, at least in government. But there's a new avenue for those who would like to censor what you say and think, and that's corporations.

The Left have wised up to this. If you want to stop someone from telling the truth, use companies to do it, the social media giants, and they are. So far, the most prominent casualty of the crusade against free expression has been the radio show host Alex Jones.

But, are we smart to think censorship will stop with him? Mark Penn is a former advisor to Bill Clinton, he is a liberal who still believes in the free exchange of ideas, and he joins us tonight. So thank you Mark for coming on.

So, I'm fascinated by the Alex Jones story, because it was Alex Jones. Almost no conservatives rose to his defense, because the idea was, well Alex Jones, yuck. But it's not really about Alex Jones, is it? It's about the idea that companies can make it impossible for your voice to be heard. Is that a precedent we should be comfortable with?

MARK PENN, FORMER ADVISOR TO BILL CLINTON: Well I really think you have to be worried about big tech becoming Big Brother.

CARLSON: Yes.

PENN: Because this used to be neutral platforms that said we're open to free expression, that's our core value, and now they've said, well not so much. With particularly Facebook hiring 10,000 new sensors on top of another 10,000, and having roving censoring bots looking for content.

Look, I never read Alex Jones, but here's somebody with millions of followers, publicly accountable for his speech, operating within Supreme Court standards, yanked from the media. That's a surprise to me, that says that these platforms are no longer as open as they presented themselves to be.

CARLSON: And it's not just him, there are many like him who've been yanked, lesser-known but still, so this has political implications. You ran and managed campaigns for so long, this must have occurred.

A lot of our political debate takes place on social media platforms, so if they clamp down on one side of the debate, why wouldn't that influence in elections outcome?

PENN: Well obviously, it could have a big influence on elections, increasingly because where people turn for their news is that they look at the news feeds that are run by the major social media companies. And so, they're more powerful than any TV station, more powerful than Fox.

CARLSON: Yes, they are.

PENN: Because of the amount of time that people spend, and it's a funnel. So, if you're not at the top, you don't get seen. And so, in the past, they had some neutral ways of doing this. But now they've increasingly applied still more mysterious algorithms plus individual sensors.

And remember, they are private platforms they say, so they're not actually subject to the First Amendment, unless we get some legislation here that says free speech is an Internet right.

CARLSON: It's totally meaningless. If I own a toll road, I can't say anyone of a certain race can drive on my toll road. And so they're not actually fully private companies, we have a public interest I would say in keeping them free and open. Why aren't, if you cared about the integrity of our elections, why isn't Congress acting?

PENN: I don't know why Congress isn't acting. Part of it is because, to stand up to a social media company means you could have five million people on your doorstep the next day. So, I think there's been a lot of intimidation in Congress instead of bipartisan agreement that, hey, we cannot have this kind of regulation of speech where whoever runs one of the big platforms can pick out speech, which speech goes and which piece doesn't.

Not when they've been exempted from the libel laws, when they've been set up as open platforms, and they now become media companies instead. And that's exactly what's happened. They've become media companies that take ads on the media that they run, and they have editors and algorithms and bots that run it.

CARLSON: I really believe that ten years from now this segment, what you just said, will be seen as prescient. I mean I think it's a big story that's being ignored by virtually everyone for reasons I don't fully understand. Maybe you're right, it's cowardice, but it shouldn't be.

Mark Penn, thank you for that.

PENN: Thank you.

CARLSON: The Chinese government plans to rank all 1.4 billion of its citizens according to their political reliability. That's pretty great. Up next, details.

CARLSON: Nearly one out of every five human beings on the planet lives in China; that's almost 1.4 billion people total. To give you some sense of scale, the United States has less than 0.4 billion total. That's a lot of people.

Now, the Communist Chinese government wants to give every single one of these people a ranking. Chinese officials plan to use technology to collect and analyze people for their new social credit system, which will then allow the government to administer punishment and of course hand out rewards, the carrot and the stick, based on good and bad behavior.

Political obedience, of course, will be central to this. It's basically naughty and nice, but there's no Santa in this calculation. What does this mean and could it come here? Gordon Chang is author of The Coming Collapse of China and he joins us. Gordon, thank you very much for coming on.

So, is -- I mean this is such a dystopian vision that a government could exert this level of social control over a population this large. It's hard to believe this could happen. Is this actually going to happen?

GORDON CHANG, AUTHOR, THE COMING COLLAPSE OF CHINA: Well, it certainly is happening right now. What we have in China is that there's so many people there, of course, the government wants to control them. And so, what they're doing is they're collecting data. They're collecting data from 600 million cameras that they'll have in place.

In 2020, they're going to have you know traffic checks, all the rest of it. This is being rolled out and it's being rolled out very quickly. So for instance, you've got people who are not allowed to board planes and trains because their social credit score is far too low.

CARLSON: So this is the kind of thing, since our ruling class pays such close attention to human rights abuses abroad and we're always worried about Myanmar and what are they doing to journalists in Moscow, I mean this seems like a glaring civil rights violation -- human rights violation. Why do we never hear anything about it from the self-appointed moral watchdogs atop our society?

CHANG: That's a great question and I actually don't know the answer for it because this is the biggest human rights abuse in the world today. And we have China doing -- putting people basically into internment camps in northwestern China, one million, people this is a crime against humanity. We don't hear about that either. And the thing that we -- I think we will hear about it, is when they roll out this system for foreigners. So we know that the Chinese government is tracking Chinese in the United States; they are actually contacting people in the US. This is just going to get worse and worse until the US government pushes back.

CARLSON: What about the tech companies, our tech companies, that exert so much social control over our society? Have they issued an unequivocal statement against this, or do we suspect they sympathize with this idea?

CHANG: I think they probably sympathize because they sold much of the technology to the Chinese that they've used, incorporated into their system. Now of course, the Chinese have been able to improve what they've gotten, but nonetheless they would not be anywhere near their level of perfection if it weren't for US and other Western companies.

CARLSON: I mean, do we send them torture equipment too for political prisoners? I mean, what -- at some point, can a company do something that's so morally repulsive that there's an outcry about it? I mean the idea that American tech companies are abetting this garbage is unbelievable.

CHANG: It is unbelievable and also, we've got American companies in Shenyang which is that region in northwestern China where you have, you know, the attempt to eradicate the Muslim religion. Well, you know, we have US companies with big operations in Shenyang and you know, they shouldn't be in China anyway. But nonetheless, to be at the site of a human rights violation which is the worst in the world, it just -- it's just indescribable as you put it.

CARLSON: I'll keep that in mind next time the Google guys want to lecture me about my moral shortcomings. Gordon Chang, thank you very much. Great to see you.

CHANG: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: A professor, a feminist at an overrated and very expensive Northeastern College, says that "Women have every right to hate men, all men, because men have done women wrong, all women by all men." Obviously demented and yet someone who agrees has been located and will join us next.

CARLSON: Well, here's the non-shocking story of the week. The Chair of the Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Department in Northeastern University feels what she calls legitimate rage against men, all men, and believes that it "makes sense for women to have rage against a group of people that has systematically abused them," she said non grammatically. In The Washington Post Opinions piece, the professor demanded that men stop running for political office, said men shouldn't be in charge of anything anyway after all, she wrote, we have every right to hate you.

Jason Nichols is a professor at the University of Maryland and he joins us. Professor, great to see.

JASON NICHOLS, PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND: Great to see you.

CARLSON: Why is it that we turn our children over to the care of the least happy, least mentally stable, least impressive people in our society? Is there anyone unhappier than this woman do you think in America?

NICHOLS: Well, look, I mean first of all, she has the right to say what she.

CARLSON: For sure she does and I'll defend it.

NICHOLS: .and she has, you know, these -- we have a big attack on academic freedom. We have to stand up for people to have the right to say certain things, even if we disagree with them now, I think lot of what she is saying is actually.

CARLSON: If I was taking her class and I took some Women's Studies courses in college because I wanted an easy grade, and they're so dumb. It's not hard as long as you hate yourself.

NICHOLS: Come to Maryland (INAUDIBLE).

CARLSON: Sure. So, let me be honest, if I stood up and said, you know, I am a man and how dare you attack all men on a collective basis, how do you think I would do in her class?

NICHOLS: I think you would do fine.

CARLSON: Right, amazing (ph).

NICHOLS: The reason being show me her evaluations, are students out there saying Professor Walters, I believe her name is, Professor Walters treated (ph) mystery to me because.

CARLSON: I don't know. The whole system (INAUDIBLE).

NICHOLS: So they knew, we (ph) getting into high pathetic-ness.

CARLSON: Of course, we are. But if she stood up and said, I dislike any -- fill in the blank some ethnic group, Polynesians. I was mugged by a Polynesian; I hate them. I've every right to hate them. If you're a Polynesian kid, I think you would have a right to say, "Gee, can I be treated fairly in this class?

NICHOLS: Right.

CARLSON: That's a reasonable.

NICHOLS: But, again that's - again, that's apples and oranges. You know that men are the people who are in power. When we look at Fortune 500 companies, 4.5% of Fortune 500 companies have women CEOs,

CARLSON: What does that mean (INAUDIBLE).

NICHOLS: And the women are the majority.

CARLSON: OK. Head of the most powerful country in Europe is a woman. I mean, I guess that the point actually that I would make.

NICHOLS: And we've never had a female leader.

CARLSON: .is that you can't -- you can't and you shouldn't ever make collective judgments about people on the basis of things they can't control.

NICHOLS: Yes. So, but what is the judgment that she's making, she's saying that patriarchy exists, that women are oppressed by men. Those things are true.

CARLSON: But not all women are oppressed by men; that's a lie. And it's also a sign of mental illness to really believe.

NICHOLS: So you don't believe that.

CARLSON: .that every woman is oppressed by every man. That's so demented. (INAUDIBLE).

NICHOLS: So you don't -- no one ever said that every woman was oppressed by every man.

CARLSON: (INAUDIBLE).

NICHOLS: She's saying that patriarchy is a system that has existed for hundreds of years in which women are suppressed. And again, I can give you many examples not only in our society, but in societies.

CARLSON: OK. It's very hard for me not to keep on with the invective because she's so dumb that it shocks me she could teach in a college, OK. But, I'll set that aside and ask if you believe that, how can you occupy a paying job in a university that a woman should be sitting in?

NICHOLS: Well, again, I think that -- I didn't agree with everything (INAUDIBLE).

CARLSON: If you want to fight (ph), look.

NICHOLS: I think there are ways to fight patriarchy.

CARLSON: How about resigning? Give your job to woman.

NICHOLS: .where you don't have to resign and give jobs.

CARLSON: Wouldn't that be pretty effective?

NICHOLS: I think one of the effective ways to do it is to recognize and be willing to accept female leadership. That's what she's really saying.

CARLSON: No, I think what she's really saying is you should resign.

NICHOLS: I don't think that's what she is saying.

CARLSON: .if patriarchy is real and give your job to a woman.

NICHOLS: I don't think that that's what she said and the argument should be systemic. That's where I actually had an issue with the way it was presented.

CARLSON: Not every man is the same, just like every member of any ethnic group is what I'm saying.

NICHOLS: But every man needs to recognize women and be open to female leadership which many men are not and that's the problem.

CARLSON: Women should be open to treating men as individuals and not as a group.

NICHOLS: Yes, I think that that has happened historically. But right now, we need for men to be open to female leadership.

CARLSON: OK, when you resign, call me. Professor, good to (ph) see you.

NICHOLS: Yes, I'll call you for a job.

CARLSON: Greg Gutfeld thinks our robot overlords are coming and he applauds their arrival. He's here next to explain.

CARLSON: Science fiction is quickly becoming reality in Russia, not for the first time. One Russian company has unveiled a 13-foot 5-ton bulletproof robot. It can't move yet but the Russians say they expect eventually they'll be able to use its giant claws to perform battlefield tasks and hold weapons.

Meanwhile in San Francisco, a restaurant is serving robot-made burgers but are today's robot chefs tomorrow's robot overlords? That's the concern. Greg Gutfeld is of course the co-host of The Five, author of The Gutfeld Monologues: Classic Rants from the Five, and he joins us tonight.

I'm very concerned about our coming robot overlords. Should I?

GREG GUTFELD, HOST OF THE GREG GUTFELD SHOW AND CO-HOST OF THE FIVE, FOX NEWS CHANNEL: Embrace it. Number one, what you just saw in Russia is not a robot; it's a car made of wood with arms and legs. That is it.

CARLSON: That's probably true.

GUTFELD: It is; it is. It's not going anywhere. There's no video. It's kind of sad. I feel bad for him. Yakov Smirnoff is probably inside that car right now telling jokes. Number two, I'm all for the robots overtaking the world but not in our food service industry, because what's going to happen is you're going to get a whole new organic movement. Organic is natural foods. Now people will have organic restaurants where people will serve it and people will cook it; that will be deemed organic.

And then there will be a fight between robots and humans and we will lose. And just like on every other planet, Tucker, while there are -- we never hear from other planets because they're all run by robots.

CARLSON: That - OK. That doesn't actually make me feel better though.

GUTFELD: Well, it shouldn't. It should - well, be like me, I'm like Benedict Arnold. I'm a traitor to the robots. I am behind the robot take -- for example, there are studies that show that judges deny or -- deny parole based on their appetite. We don't need to replace chefs; we need to replace judges with robots, and then life would be better.

By the way, everything when you put a robot before anything, it makes it better. Robot dogs are better, robot answer better, robot Tucker would be better than Tucker, but by a little (ph).

CARLSON: I feel threatened. I mean I'm with you on the first part. I do welcome our new insect overlords and look forward to seeing their sugar caves. But I don't know why the rest of us sit back passively and allow even the potential for technology to start giving us orders when we're supposed to be in charge of technology?

GUTFELD: Well, the good news is that we could always unplug them and they all have a battery. But here's the thing, we're not because we're going to come to rely on them the same way we rely on our phones. Essentially, we've already implanted technology into our bodies. It's our phone which is connected to our hand which is now basically an external drive for our brain, right?

We carry this around. It's got everything we could ever need in the world from, you know, every book you ever want to read. That's your external drive. Robots are just going to take care of us and they're going to be awesome, Tucker. You're going to love it. It's going to be great. But you don't want them to cook your food; you want humans.

CARLSON: I just read your book and in the acknowledgments, you do not mention the robot who wrote it.

GUTFELD: Yes. Well, you know what, he's a ghost robot writer. He is a robot ghost.

CARLSON: That's the beauty of robots; they don't need credit. They don't need credit; now you're winning me over.

GUTFELD: You don't have to pay them. They don't have bathroom breaks. They don't have smoke breaks. They don't poop. They're perfect; I'm telling you that's why you need robot judges. No emotion, Tucker. What's the worst thing we're seeing right now, emotion replacing thought, right?

CARLSON: It's true.

GUTFELD: And so, if you have a robot as a judge, there's no emotion. It's perfect. Robots should be making all of our decisions while we kick back and eat the glorious, glorious food created by loving people.

CARLSON: That's why I hate robots because they're more impressive than I am.

GUTFELD: No.

CARLSON: Gutfeld, also more impressive. Great to see you, thank you.

GUTFELD: Thank you.

CARLSON: That's it for us tonight. Sadly, another hour gone. Tune in every night, including tomorrow at 8 PM to the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and groupthink, which are almost overwhelming right now. You ought to pledge to fight back; that's the only way it will stop. In the meantime, good night from Washington. Guess who's next? Sean Hannity.

SEAN HANNITY, HOST, THE SEAN HANNITY SHOW: I'm waiting.

CARLSON: Three minutes or seconds early.

HANNITY: Tucker, good to see you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RXM-B871-JB4M-V11T-00000-00Bill enabling prosecutors, victims to pursue websites that host sex traffickers heads to White House2018-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill enabling prosecutors, victims to pursue websites that host sex traffickers heads to White HouseTom Jackman

The Senate on Wednesday passed a bill, already approved by the House, that would enable prosecutors to pursue websites that host advertisements for prostitution. The bill, awaiting President Trump's signature, was hailed by anti-sex-trafficking groups and law enforcement as an important step in fighting online prostitution of teenagers.

Senators passed the bill 97 to 2, without amendments, meaning it can be immediately signed into law by the president. White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said in a statement that Trump applauded the passage of the bill, said it was "an important step forward," and that the president looked forward to putting "an end to this scourge," but she did not explicitly say he would sign the bill. Sens. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) and Rand Paul (R-Ky.) were the only "no" votes.

The bill would amend the Communications Decency Act, which websites such as Backpage.com have invoked as immunity from criminal and civil actions when victims of online sex trafficking have tried to stop them from hosting ads for male and female sex workers, some of whom are teenagers. The act was passed in 1996, as the Internet was just evolving.

The 1996 measure protects website operators from content posted by third parties, so long as the operators have no involvement in the content, and it is credited with enabling the Internet to flourish without excessive regulation or legal liability for small start-ups. When young women who had been prostituted on Backpage tried to sue the website, federal appeals courts in Chicago and Boston specifically cited the Communications Decency Act's Section 230 as precluding the women from holding the websites liable.

Those rulings spurred the move to amend the law. In Chicago, a 16-year-old girl was slain by a customer who had found her on Backpage in 2016. In Washington state, a 15-year-old girl was trafficked on Backpage for more than three months before being rescued. But the mothers of both girls faced uphill legal battles against Backpage, so both mothers gave emotional testimony to Congress in support of amending Section 230 to enable prosecution of the websites themselves.

"It is a good day for America," said Nacole S., the mother of the Washington girl, whose last name is being withheld to protect the girl's identity. "The narrow focus of this bill corrects Section 230 and keeps with the original intent of Internet freedom and holds bad actors accountable for trafficking our children. This means everything to our family, and it is the fulfillment of a promise to our daughter to hold those [actors] accountable."

Linda Smith, founder of Shared Hope International, an anti-sex-trafficking group, said she began providing research to Congress in 2007 about online sex trafficking but that the information wasn't taken seriously. "We were all waking up," Smith said. "Congress is not much different from the rest of the country. People are recognizing that these children are victims of crime and deserve justice. That vote is, I think, historic."

A Senate subcommittee investigated Backpage and found that it was involved in editing prostitution ads on its site to remove references to underage girls, while allowing the ads to stay on the site. A Washington Post investigation last year revealed that Backpage representatives actively solicited ads from prostitutes who advertised on other sites and created ads for them on Backpage. Legislation then launched in the House and Senate to amend Section 230, specifying that it did not indemnify websites from facilitating sex trafficking.

A hybrid version of those bills emerged from the House, under Rep. Ann Wagner's (R-Mo.) proposed law titled "Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act of 2017," or "FOSTA," and passed last month. Sen. Rob Portman (R-Ohio) championed a similar bill in the Senate and spoke repeatedly on the chamber floor in recent days about the need for it to stop or slow down online sex trafficking.

Large tech companies, such as Google and Facebook, initially declared their opposition to the bills, saying they would create massive liability for content they simply couldn't monitor. But law enforcement and anti-human trafficking groups waged an effective campaign in support of the bills, and Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg announced her support for the bill, as did other large tech companies.

"This is legislation that is overdue in my view," Portman said on the floor Wednesday. "And it's required. The courts have told us that. The district attorneys have told us that. The attorneys general told us that...They welcomed us to pass this legislation to give these families the justice they deserve and to give our prosecutors the ability to go after them."

The key section of "FOSTA" clarifies that Section 230 shall not impair prosecution of anyone violating federal sex trafficking laws or limit civil lawsuits, and in the sex trafficking law defines "participation in a venture" as anyone "knowingly assisting, supporting or facilitating a violation" of the law. "Now," said Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.), "all the prosecutors in the country can go after anyone who knowingly facilitates sex trafficking online."

Among the sex ads posted on Backpage.com are those for underage boys and girls, authorities and advocacy groups say. The National Association of Attorneys General has described Backpage as a "hub" of human trafficking, which involves children or adults who are forced or coerced into prostitution. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children said that 73 percent of the 10,000 child sex trafficking reports it receives from the public each year involve ads on Backpage. Recently, Backpage's ads have begun omitting any copy with their offers of adult services, instead showing only photographs of the purported escorts.

Still, there was opposition to the bill. Wyden, one of the original sponsors of Section 230 in 1996, said the Justice Department already could prosecute Backpage for the violations revealed by the Senate investigation. He said the bill would be a bonanza for trial lawyers, who could sue websites for content they weren't aware of, and "dismantle the legal framework that's given the United States the position it holds as a tech-economy superpower." Wyden said big tech companies ultimately supported the bill because "it rolls up the ladder in the tech world, leaving the established giants alone at the top" and smaller companies susceptible to punishing lawsuits.

"This bill will be something the Senate will deeply regret," Wyden said.

IBM reiterated its support for the bill shortly after the vote, issuing a statement which said it "looks forward to seeing FOSTA signed quickly into law," and that "those who knowingly help sex traffickers use the internet to commit despicable crimes are closer than ever before to being held accountable.

Some who study or work with sex workers said the bill would not impact the problem of online sex trafficking of minors, and make it harder to find victims. Kimberly Mehlman-Orozco, author of the book "Hidden in Plain Sight: America's Slaves of the New Millennium," said "the justification for this legislation rests on the misleading idea that individual websites facilitate child sex trafficking, when in reality the Internet as whole has brought this practice out of the shadows and proliferated it. Once signed into law, FOSTA will likely be used to go after previously vilified websites, like Backpage.com and Craigslist.org, despite the fact that those platforms have been used as critical tools for law enforcement and facilitate the rescues of victims and arrests of offenders. Meanwhile, other websites that are also used by sex traffickers, like Facebook, will continue business as usual."

But others heralded the bill's passage. John M. Simpson of Consumer Watchdog said FOSTA was "a major step forward not only for families of children who were trafficked, but for everyone who cares about holding tech giants accountable to the rule of law. This is a chink in the teflon of Google and Facebook's shield of immunity," and force them to reevaluate their "duties to police their platforms"

Yiota Souras, general counsel for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, said when the bill is enacted, "not only will it untie the hands of every state Attorney General's office across the country to enter the fight against online sex trafficking, but it will open the door for private attorneys to serve as a voice for individual survivors in civil lawsuits against their online traffickers.  Most importantly, this bill creates a bright line to root out bad actors online who knowingly participate in the trafficking of children and vulnerable adults while it continues the CDA's protection of online entities that engage in voluntary good faith efforts to remove trafficking and sexually exploitative content online."

urn:contentItem:608C-C7R1-JC8G-81WK-00000-00Bill From Graham, Blumenthal Divides Encryption, Victim Advocates2020-06-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:54ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSBill From Graham, Blumenthal Divides Encryption, Victim Advocates

It's unlikely Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., could offer an amendment to keep the Earn It Act from undermining encryption for millions of Americans, encryption advocates said in interviews about Thursday's Senate Judiciary Committee markup (see 2006250067). A victims advocate urged the committee to advance the bill, contending government action is the only way to get Big Tech to respond to rampant child exploitation.

Tech companies are interested only in blocking legislation and regulation, said National Center on Sexual Exploitation General Counsel Benjamin Bull. He urged industry to work with Blumenthal and Chairman Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., in shaping the bill rather than fighting it. The industry's complacency left Congress no choice, he argued, saying child predators and traffickers run rampant on platforms like Instagram, Snapchat and TikTok.

Computer and Communications Industry Association President Matt Schruers said the Earn it Act will force companies to weaken industry-standard security and encryption measures. It's also problematic because of its impact on Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, allowing the government to manage speech on platforms, he said. The Internet Association cited a recent blog post raising concerns the Earn It Act would allow criminal defendants in child exploitation cases to suppress evidence with Fourth Amendment arguments.

Blumenthal said he might seek to clarify encryption aspects of the bill. Graham said he wants to keep the encryption debate separate. Fixing the encryption aspects might be possible, but that's not the only issue with the bill, Schruers said. CCIA also opposes a bill from Graham and Republicans that would let police lawfully access encrypted data (see 2006240064). To convenience law enforcement, it would make products and phones less safe, Schruers said: Any time companies are mandated to keep keys under doormats, it's an invitation for bad actors to find those keys.

There's nothing Blumenthal could do to clarify the Earn It Act to avoid weakening encryption, said New America's Open Technology Institute Senior Policy Analyst Andi Wilson Thompson. OTI doesn't support Graham's encryption bill either, she said: It's impossible to guarantee police access to encrypted communications without harming user security, she said, and the Earn It Act is another effort by DOJ to weaken encryption.

Access Now opposes both bills, said Legislative Manager Jennifer Brody. Assigning a government commission to decide how Section 230 applies to companies will have a chilling impact on speech and content moderation, she said of the Earn It Act. Brody agreed with the general sentiment of a bill from Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., that would direct $5 billion for investigations and resources about online child abuse (see 2005060015).

The National Center on Sexual Exploitation also supports Wyden's bill, but increasing investigatory resources doesn't solve the whole problem, Bull said. Internet regulation is the only way to resolve child exploitation issues, he said, because Big Tech is unwilling to act. Congress is either going to regulate, or FTC and DOJ enforcers are going to intervene with antitrust cases, he said.

Legislators need to account for victims of stalking and harassment when revisiting Section 230, said Future of Privacy Forum Vice President-Policy John Verdi. If there's an area of improvement, it starts with individuals who have been victimized, he said. FPF hasn't taken a position on the Earn It Act or Graham's encryption bill. Verdi voiced support for an "accurate and fulsome" discussion on the benefits of strong encryption.

urn:contentItem:5X3K-8B81-DY0W-40F4-00000-00Bill Gates: Breaking up big tech companies 'doesn’t seem like a solution'2019-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill Gates: Breaking up big tech companies 'doesn’t seem like a solution'Melissa QuinnWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

Microsoft founder Bill Gates, whose company faced a federal antitrust dispute two decades ago, warned against the break up of big tech companies.

That puts him at odds with some lawmakers as they seek to rein in Silicon Valley titans.

In a recent interview with Bloomberg TV, Gates questioned whether breaking up tech companies that have been accused of engaging in monopolistic practices is the right way to curb the behavior.

“You have to really think, is that the best thing?” Gates said. “If there’s a way the company is behaving that you want to get rid of, then you should just say, ‘OK, that’s a banned behavior.’ But splitting the company in two and having two people doing the bad thing, that doesn’t seem like a solution.”

Gates couldn’t recall the last time a company was broken up and said a “pretty narrow set of things” would warrant such action.

The tech industry’s biggest and most powerful companies, including Google, Amazon, and Facebook, have recently come under scrutiny by federal and state officials for what they say are efforts to keep smaller competitors out of the market. The Justice Department announced this summer a federal antitrust review into “market-leading online platforms,” and the Federal Trade Commission has launched its own investigation into the practices of big tech companies.

State attorneys general have also undertaken their own efforts to probe the titans of Silicon Valley, who have been accused of having outsized dominance.

But Gates said tech companies are “behaving totally legally.”

“They’re doing a lot of innovative things,” he said.

Gates’ Microsoft was embroiled in an antitrust battle with the Justice Department and a coalition of state attorneys general in the late 1990s over allegations it illegally attempted to monopolize the market for internet browsers by bundling its browser, Internet Explorer, with Windows.

A federal district court ruled against Microsoft in the case and ordered the company be broken up into two, but a federal appeals court overturned the ruling in 2001. Microsoft remains as one company today.

Democratic presidential contender Elizabeth Warren has been a vocal proponent of breaking up big tech companies and has detailed a plan for how to do so. But Gates instead said the government should impose more regulations on tech companies, something Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has also called for.

"I do think government really needs to talk about what those rules should be," Gates said. "It's not, you could say, unbiased, but I see these as well-meaning, highly innovative companies, that it's up to society to make sure that their innovation doesn't have negative side effects."iFrame Object

Photo Caption:Bill Gates, chairman of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, attends the "Africa Leadership Meeting - Investing in Health Outcomes" held at a hotel in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia Saturday, Feb. 9, 2019.

urn:contentItem:5RNF-4FC1-F08D-54J9-00000-00Bill Gates diz que as grandes empresas de tecnologia estão convidando a regulamentação governamental2018-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill Gates diz que as grandes empresas de tecnologia estão convidando a regulamentação governamental

Bill Gates adverte que as grandes empresas tecnológicas não estão preocupadas o suficiente com a regulamentação governamental, em uma nova entrevista com a Axios hoje. Continue reading Bill Gates diz que as grandes empresas de tecnologia estão convidando a regulamentação governamental

Bill Gates adverte que as grandes empresas tecnológicas não estão preocupadas o suficiente com a regulamentação governamental, em uma nova entrevista com a Axios hoje. Chamando a Apple e outros gigantes da tecnologia , Gates argumenta que as empresas estão convidando a intervenção governamental ao demonstrar a arrogância, dizendo que precisam ser cuidadoso que não estão tentando pensar que sua visão é mais importante do que a visão do governo ou governo capaz de funcionar em algumas áreas-chave .

Quando Axios perguntou a Gates por exemplo, ele disse: o entusiasmo por tornar as transações financeiras anônimas e invisíveis, e sua visão de que até mesmo uma comunicação clara do criminoso assassino em massa nunca deveria estar disponível para o governo . Quando pressionado sobre se Gates significava ser capaz para desbloquear um iPhone, ele respondeu: Não há dúvida de habilidade; é a questão da vontade .

Esta resposta parece referenciar a disputa entre o FBI e a Apple ao obter acesso a um iPhone conectado ao tiroteio de San Bernardino em 2015. Embora o FBI finalmente invadiu o telefone sem a ajuda da Apple, a Apple lutou contra a agência sobre o assunto, prometendo que seria ir ao tribunal para proteger a privacidade do usuário. Desde o início, nós opomos à demanda do FBI de que a Apple criasse uma porta traseira no iPhone, porque acreditávamos que era errado e criaria um precedente perigoso , afirmou a empresa em um comunicado na época. A Apple acredita profundamente que as pessoas nos Estados Unidos e em todo o mundo merecem proteção de dados, segurança e privacidade. Sacrificar um para o outro apenas coloca as pessoas e os países em maior risco .

No momento da disputa, Gates disse publicamente que sentia que as preocupações da Apple eram infundadas, pois o pedido solicitado apenas era aplicado a um único dispositivo e não um acesso generalizado a todos os dispositivos da Apple. Ninguém está falando sobre um backdoor este é um caso específico onde o governo está pedindo acesso à informação. Eles não estão pedindo uma coisa geral, eles estão pedindo um caso particular , Gates disse ao Financial Times em 2016. Os novos comentários de Gates sobre a questão da vontade parecem reforçar a conclusão de que a Apple tem os meios para invadir um telefone individual, mas escolhe não fazê-lo.

A Gates expressou anteriormente sua opinião sobre estabelecer um equilíbrio entre o acesso do governo aos dados criptografados, mantendo a segurança e a privacidade dos usuários em uma AMA da Reddit no ano passado. Talvez eles possam propor um plano geral para encontrar o equilíbrio entre o governo capaz de conhecer as coisas em alguns casos e ter salvaguardas para garantir que esses poderes sejam limitados aos casos apropriados , escreveu Gates. Não há como evitar esse debate e eles podem contribuir para a forma como o equilíbrio deve ser atingido .

urn:contentItem:5X2V-XWS1-JCMN-Y4VM-00000-00Bill Gates doesn't think breakups are the solution to big tech's problems2019-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill Gates doesn't think breakups are the solution to big tech's problemsShawn Knight

Sep 17, 2019( TechSpot: http://www.techspot.com Delivered by Newstex) Why it matters: Gates is no stranger to antitrust regulators, having publicly gone against the US government during his time at Microsoft in a highly publicized antitrust case in the late 90s. That experience makes what he has to say all the more interesting. Bill Gates in a recent interview with Bloomberg Television's Erik Schatzke weighs in on the government's recent probe[1] into the practices of big technology companies like Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.

In a nutshell, Gates said that if a company is behaving badly, the best course of action would be to address the matter directly. 'You should just say, okay, that's a banned behavior.' Splitting a company into two and having two entities doing a bad thing doesn't seem like a solution, he said.Gates added that there is a pretty narrow list of things in which a breakup is the right answer to.[embedded content]Touching on another sensitive topic, taxes, Gates said companies are behaving totally legally and doing a lot of innovative things with regard to how they structure themselves for the purpose of tax breaks. 'People should look if they want to change that going forward, that's the real question.'As for social media, Gates said nobody had a crystal ball and could have known that these platforms would radicalize people or split them into different groups. 'What the solution should be - you know, have us reading a common front page and not being pulled to extremes,' isn't necessarily the responsibility of tech companies. 'Government really needs to talk about what those rules should be,' he said. Instead, 'it's up to society to make sure [that the innovation of big tech companies] don't have negative side effects.'Masthead credit: Bill Gates[2] by Frederic Legrand - COMEO Related Reads Share this article: https://www.techspot.com/news/81939-bill-gates-doesnt-think-breakups-solution-big-tech.html#Share   https://www.reddit.com/submit?url=https://www.techspot.com/news/81939-bill-gates-doesnt-think-breakups-solution-big-tech.html...le=Bill%20Gates%20doesn't%20think%20breakups%20are%20the%20solution%20to%20big%20tech's%20problems [ 1]:   https://www.techspot.com/news/81108-justice-department-wants-take-closer-look-tech-giants.html [ 2]:   https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/paris-france-april-16-2018-bill-1070620838

urn:contentItem:5V07-MDD1-F03R-N54S-00000-00Bill Gates: Government Should Be Talking More Regulation With Big Tech Companies, 'I Was Naive'2018-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:24:55ZLexisNexisBill Gates: Government Should Be Talking More Regulation With Big Tech Companies, 'I Was Naive'Josh Feldman

Dec 14, 2018( Mediaite: http://www.mediaite.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ; Watch the latest video at foxnews.com[1]Fox News Sunday anchor Chris Wallace scored an interview with Bill Gates and asked him about the backlash in Washington to big tech. 'The growing feeling in Washington,' Wallace said, 'is that big tech does not do enough to protect users' privacy and that it shows political bias. Do you see merit in either of those arguments?' Gates immediately said that of course the government 'should be talking to these companies about what they do.' 'There's nothing inappropriate,' he acknowledged. 'I was naive. I didn't have an office in Washington, D.C., I thought that was a good thing, and I even bragged about it. I later came to regret that. So I'm sure these guys are learning better than I did, that they need to come back here and start a dialogue and there will be new types of regulation for these companies.' The full interview airs on Fox News Sunday this weekend. You can watch the clip above, via Fox News.
